speakeroldname: Mr. Robert D. Nault (Kenora-Rainy River) moved:
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the government should move
immediately to appoint an independent commission to undertake an
in-depth study of labour relations in areas of federal jurisdiction.
He said: Good morning, Mr. Speaker, and welcome back to all members. Of course, we all missed this place dearly and are glad to be back.
I would like first to explain the motion. One of the questions that was asked of me when we put the private members' motions together was whether a motion would be votable or non-votable.
I decided from the outset not to make it a votable motion. I did not want to force the government to feel obliged to deal with the issue in a partisan way, but to look at the facts and to try and get a sense from the discussions which we will have in this short period of time as to the importance of the issue, what is confronting us in the long term, and of course the ramifications down the road of the labour relations in this country for us as Canadian people as we enter into the global market.
First of all, in the short time that I have, in the next 20 minutes, I want to try and outline just what has taken place and what some of the issues are that this particular inquiry can look at.
Let me also say that there are times when the Canadian public feels very frustrated about inquiries or commissions and the cost of them. I want to suggest that
I think everyone in this place can agree that we have come a long way since 1968. There has been a tremendous amount of change. There have also been some issues that we have tried to deal with in this place and in other places, of course, such as the provincial jurisdiction.
What is hoped by the in-depth inquiry which we may be done, by some proficient Canadians is that we could enter into the 1990s and beyond with a new way of doing business. As you know, every time there are difficult periods in our history-some call them depressions, some call them recessions, some call them blips, some call them bust and boom cycles-when those periods take place, all of a sudden new words emerge.
The new word for government members opposite is "partnership". They are talking very extensively now out there to labour relations people, to unions, to workers, about the importance of having a partnership, of being co-operative, of having team-work in order that we can globally compete out there against other countries for jobs and to make a living in all sectors of the economy.
That is very well and good. We recommend that people try to co-operate. If we are going to ask people to co-operate, to have team-work and to enter into a partnership, the rules have to be such that it is fair for those who are participating, that it is not skewed one way, that it is not take by one particular group and give by another.
That is really the issue that I want to deal with today. I want to do that by using a couple of examples. At the same time, before I get into the examples, I just want to inform the public that there are some difficulties out

April 27, 1992
Private Members' Business
there. That is the reason it is important that we take a look at this issue and why we should study it thoroughly.
For example, in 1991, there were 31 labour disputes in the federal jurisdiction. That is a large number. Some will recall in The Ottawa Citizen of not too long ago, a few weeks ago, it explained to us in detail the number of person-days lost to strikes in 1991.
All of us in this place know that there have been some difficult strikes. We as parliamentarians have had to legislate people back to work because of those difficulties. Our Public Service employees, of course, come to mind. Postal workers and grain handlers are others. For those who may not be familiar, the railroads are now in the process of negotiation. Again, we may be forced, if it comes to that, to look at that issue as well.
Ottawa leads the way in strikes in 1991 with 1.1 million lost person-days. Montreal, of course, is second with 353,470. Toronto lost 291,073; Vancouver lost 154,207; Edmonton lost 122,318; and Calgaiy lost 89,942. Those are a lot of lost days. A tremendous amount of competitiveness and productivity has gone down the tube because of these strikes.
That is why we as parliamentarians should take a very positive route, take a look at the issues and try to come to some sort of understanding of whether there is a necessity to make changes in the labour relations process in this country.
I want to read into the record what was said in 1968 by the then Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson at his press conference of September 2, 1966. When he launched the inquiry, the Prime Minister said: "To look into this whole question of labour disputes and the procedures and provisions of the current laws, we have to deal with them and to recommend to the government changes that may be required".
In the study itself as a result of the Prime Minister's recommendations to have a study, paragraph 2 of the task force introduction reads: "Why has the public apparently lost faith in the prevailing collective bargaining process? The rash of strikes which have caught the headlines in recent years provides much of the explanation".
"In many of these disputes, the protagonists seem to suffer less than the public. Worse still, there is apprehension that the parties are using the public as their whipping boy while they work out their differences".
That does not sound too different today than it did 24 years ago. I suggest that if it makes sense now as it did then it is time to take an in-depth look at the whole subject of labour relations.
We should look at it in the context of the major issue of collective bargaining versus public policy, versus industrial strategy and industrial policy for us as a country in order that we can be very competitive out there with other countries.
Whenever there is a strike, whenever there is a dispute, whenever there is a difference of opinion, somebody is affected. It is not just the workers, but the country as a whole. For us as parliamentarians it is paramount that we take a look at that particular issue with the vision of just what it entails if we allow this kind of situation to get out of hand. If this kind of situation continues to grow then all of a sudden public policy is held hostage by a process that does not seem to work.
As I said before, partnership, team-work and co-operation is a two-way street. I want to give an example of what is going on out there today in the pulp and paper industry. This is an industry very close to my heart. I come from the riding of Kenora-Rainy River that without this particular resource and industry at its full potential experiences tremendous hardships.
Lo and behold, during the 1980s we went through a very difficult recession. The pulp and paper industry was probably at its lowest in many years. The Canadian Liberal government at the time pumped billions of dollars into the pulp and paper industry.
In this place we talked about the importance of having the most up-to-date technology, the best trained workforce, the most acceptable collective bargaining process in the country for that industry. At the same time, we needed the ability as a government to help the industry to be competitive in the global market.
April 27, 1992

That was just 10 years ago. Now what do we have today?
Today in the pulp and paper industry in northwestern Ontario and in Canada we have mills shutting down. We are being told the 20 per cent over-capacity in the paper industry means that 20 per cent of the industry in Canada and in North America in general has to downsize to a point where it now can sell that excess paper. Or, of course, what it has to do is downsize to the point where those mills are shut down because they are not technologically capable of competing with our American neighbours or with Sweden and Finland.
That brings me to an issue which is of concern to me. In the pulp and paper industry today, in my own backyard, in my own home town, the company has asked the labour union to open the collective bargaining process. They have a contract now. It is not due for another year or so before they have to negotiate. It is asking to have this collective agreement opened in order to become more competitive and to change the work rules to become more flexible.
Of course there is some reluctance to do that by the employees. Why? Because they have a process. They have a collective bargaining process. They have a contract that says in essence they have negotiated with the intent of not having to look at that for another year. They signed a three-year agreement. Because of the difficulties out there, the recession, the job losses and the potential of this mill closing itself, they are literally forced to open it. This is not new to a lot of members, they could talk about this in their own areas too, as well as in other provinces.
That is the case in this industry and of course it is the case in other industries. In southern Ontario we have seen massive job losses, plants closing, plants moving to the United States, people having to look for other jobs in other industries because of the fact the company is not competitive.
Of course we as parliamentarians have to look at that issue as far as the collective bargaining process is concerned. We cannot simply say that it is business as usual, that if a company wants to shut down, especially a company that is in the resource sector like in mining or forestry, a whole town can practically disappear when that takes place.
I want to emphasize by quoting a few paragraphs from the task force of 1968. Paragraphs 6 and 7 of the task
Private Members' Business
force introduction reflect today's realities. I will read them: "To these events must be added a public predisposition to blame unions and collective bargaining for inflation which has plagued the Canadian economy in recent years".
Paragraph 7 says: "Whether these alleged ills are merely symptoms of more profound social problems is ignored by the public. Unions and collective bargaining are ready targets for public wrath".
It has been so long since we even looked at the issue and talked about it in public that people get the impression it is always the union's fault. It is because they always want too much and because wages are so high we cannot be competitive. The argument made is will we move or will we slash them down to a point where we can be competitive. However, there are some large ramifications to that.
Now is an opportune time for us to talk about the effects of the marketplace on collective bargaining and the effect of the collective bargaining process on the ability to compete. If that is true or not true, ways must be found to change the process in order for it to be more compatible to our goals as Canadians.
There are some good recommendations in that report which were never implemented. I want to touch on a few of them. One of the things I found very interesting, and it deals with unions themselves, is the fact that public policy issues are at the forefront. I want to read one of the recommendations. "We recommend that there be created a three-man public interest dispute commission, independent of any government department, reporting to the Prime Minister and composed of public members only".
This dispute commission would ensure that when there is a dispute that conflicts with the public good, that conflicts with an industrial strategy that is necessary for us to compete, we should not allow the employer to hold us hostage on the one side, and on the other side allow employees to drag the dispute into the public forum in order to get the dispute into the political arena, which is where it ends up if it drags on too long and if it has some public ramifications.
If that takes place, we as parliamentarians are always asked to legislate them back to work. This public interest dispute commission would give the opportunity for both sides to put forward their side of the dispute. It would allow the commission to recommend to the government

April 27, 1992
Private Members' Business
to look at different ways of resolving disputes without creating the hardship, the anxiety and the antagonism that goes on in the country every time we have a dispute of that magnitude.
This commission would only work if it has the interests of both parties at heart, is perceived to be fair and has the trust of both sides.
I would like to stress that when we get into this kind of study it be made as public as possible because it is my understanding, in talking to a lot of management people out there in the work force, that Canadians do not have a great understanding of unions as a whole. They do not have a great understanding of the complexities of the collective bargaining process. Because of that, when there are disputes, they tend to take their anger out on the employees who are out there picketing on what they believe to be a legitimate grievance.
I would like to see certain areas studied. The freedom to associate and to act collectively is one area that has to be studied to see why it is that certain management people are afraid to have collective bargaining or unions created in their particular industries and the difficulties that entails.
Based on the fact that I was very involved in the postal dispute, I would like us to look at unfair labour practices. I tend to think that the rules of the game have changed significantly. I would like us to take a look at labour practices and how they are dealt with.
I would like to take a look at trade unions, political action and the political process and see how trade unions are interacting with political parties and whether that is for the good of the country or not.
First, I would like to deal with management approaches and practices and how they deal with the collective bargaining process. Most important, I would like to deal with the public interest in industrial conflict and how that is changing because of the changing world that we live in.
If we can do that in a very non-partisan way, we could possibly set our sights on the future and go down the road with the understanding that we are to be co-operative. It is a two-sided coin. If we do not do that the animosity and the difficulties in the system will continue. The only way to say it is that people are starting to break the law. I hate to have to say that in this place but people are taking extreme measures to get their point across.
With this report and this study I hope we can change the way we do business. Perhaps we can update this 24-year old document and put in place a regime that will lead us into the next 10 years in a more co-operative manner. I hope the members who are participating will join in a dialogue of co-operation so that we can convince the government a report or an inquiry like this is for the good of all Canadians.

speakeroldname: Mr. Peter L. McCreath (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to have an opportunity to participate in this debate today. I commend and congratulate my hon. friend from Kenora for bringing this issue forward.
There is no question there have been disruptions that have caused a great deal of anxiety on the part of both those directly involved in those disruptions and Canadians as the whole, as he has indicated.
Just before I get into my own comments I want to bring to the House's attention a couple of things in reference to what my hon. friend said. He spoke of the pulp and paper industry. I would remind him that that industry falls within provincial jurisdiction. I presume that in an inquiry such as the one he is proposing, it would not deal with the problem he raises with respect to that industry.
He also mentioned the 1968 task force study that was done and, indeed, it was very interesting to hear the remarks he quoted. I should point out to him, however, there have been three other studies since that time. It has not been the case that this issue has not been brought forward.
In the mid-1970s there was the Finkelman report on employer-employee relations in the Public Service of Canada. In 1975 Justice E. D. Bayda reported on the state of industrial relations in the grain handling industry in the Vancouver port area. That study was followed by a more detailed assessment of the bargaining structure
April 27, 1992

and various elements of Canada's transportation system, including grain handling and rail transportation. I am referring of course to the 1978 inquiry headed by the chairperson of the Industrial Relations Department of McGill University, Dr. Francis Bairstow. Therefore, it is not as if this subject has not been given some attention.
Also it is important to point out that while this motion has arisen from four fairly high-profile labour disputes, existing legislation provides a framework for collective bargaining which is both flexible and effective and is intended to encourage peaceful resolution of disputes and in fact does so in the overwhelming majority of contract discussions.
I do not think we should lose sight of the fact that the vast majority of collective agreements are achieved without any kind of disruption or collective sanctions and, indeed, 90 per cent of those that are not settled at the table in the first instance are resolved through conciliation. What we are dealing with in terms of collective sanction actions is less than 1 per cent of the circumstances. I do not think we should overdramatize the problem. If there is one incidence of a failure to come up with an appropriate and reasonable agreement, obviously there is a problem that needs to be addressed.
I am sure all members of the House would agree the right to free collective bargaining is one of the fundamental principles of any democratic society. The right of association is the one written in civil codes, human rights declarations, and so on. Indeed, I would go further and argue that the right to withdraw one's labour is an equally fundamental right that should accrue to anybody who is involved in an employment situation.
I might say with the right and the choice to exercise that right, the individual is also opting to take certain risks in terms of what might happen to the employment they thereby choose to leave behind. Nevertheless it is as fundamental a right of the individual to choose to withdraw his or her labour as it is to have free collective bargaining.
Unions developed over 100 years ago as a result of oppressive working conditions in factories. It is an outcome of the industrial revolution and, indeed, of abuse by employers taking undue advantage of the power of their position to at times have people working in unacceptable circumstances. We have had a tremendous development of trade unions, not just in this country but
Private Members' Business
throughout much of the world. A very important role is played on behalf of employees by the unions to which they belong.
Some people in this country argue it has gone too far and that unions are too powerful. I personally do not think that is the case. If a union is powerful it is because the membership has chosen to transfer that power to it which it exercises, and as long as it acts within the law it is a perfectly legitimate circumstance.
The problem that exists today is not the problem of power but the problem of usurpation of power for political purposes by union leadership. This is inevitably what leads to a lot of the problems, including the one we had last year with the Public Service strike, where the leadership of unions took advantage of their position to pursue their own political ends, notwithstanding the best wishes of the membership.
It is important to remember that the role of a union- and this is my definition-is to protect the employment and interests of the members. That is why unions exist. That is why union members pay union dues.
I worked for the Nova Scotia teacher's union for 10 years and although a lot of people looked to the teachers' union to provide leadership in education, which we tried to do, and for professionalism within the teaching profession, which we tried to do, as an employee of that union it was my responsibility to remember that the reason they paid my salary was to look out for their interests. The most important aspect of their interest was that they had a job and good working conditions and reasonable benefits. That was why the union existed. That is why all unions exist.
Similarly, when I was a member of a union, a member of ACTRA, I paid my union dues in the expectation that the union would work for me. Some union leaders in this country seem to have forgotten that is why unions exist. Rather we see a situation where some union people see the union office as a vehicle to personal power. They see a chance to pursue their own opportunity for development and to move into the political domain.
We have seen an increasing intrusion of many unions away from its role and toward political intervention. One need only look at the relationship at the national level of some national trade unions and organizations like the CLC and the CAW with the NDP.

April 27, 1992
Private Members' Business
The linkage one sees between the CLC, the CAW and the NDP seems at times to make them indistinguishable. Does this mean that all union members who pay dues know those dues are supposed to be used for the purposes of the New Democratic Party? I do not think so.
Does it mean that all union members support the NDP? I know it is not so. I have union members serving on my executive and it galls them that their union dues are in part used to subsidize the NDP. I am sure the same feeling exists with some of my Liberal colleagues opposite and, indeed, maybe the independents who sit in this place as well.
When there is a conflict, does one assume that the unions are always going to take the position that is in the interests of the membership, or will they do what they think is in the interests of the NDP? Do all NDP positions reflect the best interests of union members? I am not so sure they do. Where is Bob White, Shirley Carr and Nancy Rich when the interests of the union members conflict with the interests of the New Democratic Party? Well, I am not so sure about that. I know that when I worked for the Nova Scotia teachers' union we felt that because we had to deal with government we should stay out of partisan politics and stick to what we were there for.
Unfortunately my former colleagues have forgotten that and got involved in a terrible partisan dispute last year with the Government of Nova Scotia which has not served the interests of teachers in Nova Scotia and, indeed, in many instances has not reflected their views.
In summary, the message to be made is that collective bargaining is fundamental and essential. When unions and their leaders forget why they exist, they may no longer serve a useful purpose to their membership and they certainly may not serve as a useful contribution to this country.
Parliamentarians are elected to govern, that is their job. The job of unions is to look after their membership.
I again congratulate my hon. friend for bringing forth this issue. I look forward to hearing what my hon. colleagues opposite have to say.

Mr. Speaker, it was very entertaining, but very evident that the hon. member for South Shore was once a member of ACTRA and has not forgotten the skills he learned there. Nor has he forgotten, or maybe he has forgotten, that while he was working for the Nova Scotia Teachers' Federation that he of course did not use any of the skills he learned whilst working on behalf of those teachers for his own personal gain, and of course never ever used any of those skills to become a member of Parliament. I am sure he had all those skills before he went to work for the workers.
I really find it quite interesting that the hon. member across the floor happened to mention, when discussing the private member's bill to have an independent commission undertake an in-depth study of labour relations in areas of federal jurisdiction, that less than 1 per cent of the unions under federal jurisdiction are up for bargaining, and that we find ourselves in a legislative quandary in this House of Commons dealing with back-to-work legislation.
If you take a look at those 1 per cent disputes, you will probably find 90 per cent of all workers under federal jurisdiction encompassed under Canada Post, the Public Service Alliance, et cetera, so it might be 1 per cent of certifications, but I would suspect it is far closer to 90 per cent of the people working under federal jurisdiction who have been legislated back in the last number of years.
I think it is important to note that a study done by Leo Panitch at York University showed that the Canadian government has the worst record of the G-7 nations regarding freedom of association. I thought it was veiy interesting to hear the hon. member for South Shore, from the the government side of the House, say that he was adamantly in support of freedom of association and the right to withdraw one's labour.
The United Nations ILO, which is the labour management arm of the United Nations, has had to deal with more complaints from Canada than from any other G-7 nation. Since 1973, one-third of all the complaints that
April 27, 1992

went to the ILO regarding freedom of association by unions came from Canada.
From 1973 to 1984 we enjoyed, with a brief interruption, 11 years of Liberal government. From 1984 to 1992 we have enjoyed eight years of Tory government. In that period of time, from 1973 to 1992, one-third of all complaints at the ILO have been from Canada concerning the area of freedom of association.
The ILO has cited the Canadian Conservative government twice in recent years for violation of the international law governing the rights and freedoms of workers. Railway and inside postal workers in Canada, both in 1987, were slapped with back-to-work orders. In fact, the ILO found the government wanting for having introduced and passed that legislation.
This past year the government supported the UN very strongly in its call for us to go to war. It was the first time in 40 years. This government supported the UN very strongly. But when it came to the rights of workers and UN international treaties governing the rights to freedom of association and protection of the right to organize that we signed in 1972, we ignored that. I think it is important we recognize that in the last number of years under both Liberal and Tory governments we have had eight back-to-work pieces of legislation under the Tory government. I am talking now since 1966. From 1966 to 1982 we had 12 Liberal back-to-work pieces of legislation. Since 1984 to the present day we have had eight Tory back-to-work pieces of legislation.
When we talk about the collective bargaining process under federal jurisdiction, I think it is important that we talk about respect and dignity. It is important that we talk about the motivation of employers and unions to bargain. I think the hon. member who has put forward this resolution is a very moderate and thoughtful man. I think his motivations were excellent in putting this forward.
What we have seen is a collective bargaining process where there is no compulsion, no motivation for the employer to get the point and fully and frankly bargain at the bargaining table. Nor is there a motivation for the union because everyone knows if you go through the steps, down the line you cannot put off the inevitable; you will get back-to-work legislation. Everyone can
Private Members' Business
blame the government and no meaningful bargaining, nor meaningful building of a relationship.
Every time we have a labour dispute, particularly one that is unresolved by the two parties and has an imposed resolution by the government, there is no healing that takes place. There is no renewing of co-operative effort. That is reflected in productivity. It is reflected in future negotiations. It is a reflection on the government and in fact reflects on how we all operate in our community.
I believe it is very important that there be a renewed look at how the collective bargaining process works and how it is failing in the federal jurisdiction. Whether it is legislative or whether it is attitudinal, I think there is a combination of factors that is causing the collective bargaining process to lead us constantly into conflict.
My goodness, in the CUPW dispute they were legislated back to work before they even went on strike. That is hardly what one would call free collective bargaining with the right to strike.
I think we also have to be aware of the fact that collective bargaining is a two-way street. The government's role should be one of facilitation. The government's role should be one of providing the forum and the facilities for both parties to come to the table and resolve outstanding issues.
It is not meant to be used as a hammer. Ultimately one has to make some effort that will make both parties sit up and pay attention. It should be the absolute last final resort.
One has to wonder why the conciliation process is not working. We saw in the Public Service Alliance negotiations with Treasury Board this past year conciliation board after conciliation board coming out with decisions and the government ignoring them. What is the point of having a conciliation board review if the government interferes or chooses to ignore the conciliation board report?
We then found ourselves in the heat of battle. The reactionary response of the government created such bitterness in the federal public sector between employer and worker that I suspect it will be a long time before that bitterness, hostility and lack of trust can be overcome in the public sector.

April 27, 1992
Private Members' Business
The other thing that is important is what motivates people to come to an amicable solution, what motivates people to work together to achieve a common outcome. Collective bargaining is about give and take. Collective bargaining is just that; it is bargaining. It is two sides coming to the table and working at resolving an issue. When we have provision for facilitation through legislation then that provision should be respected as well. We cannot expect those at the bargaining table, both employer and union, to respect the process if the government does not respect the process.
I close by saying that I think it is long overdue that there be a review of the collective bargaining process under federal jurisdiction, and I look forward to participating in it.

Mr. Speaker, the comments of the government member for South Shore who spoke just before the last speaker are a good example of why it is high time that a motion like this one was brought before this House and that a thorough look at how we can have better labour relations in this country was undertaken.
Why I say that is that the government member demonstrated everything about what is wrong with an adversarial, confrontational approach to management and to labour relations in any sector, but particularly in the public sector. Especially coming from a government member when the government has the power as employer to avoid all its obligations to negotiate collectively because it knows it can rely on legislation instead of negotiation to come to a contract with its employees. With that kind of power, government members should also realize their responsibility to respect people's rights to have decent and fair working conditions, to be able to negotiate with their employer, and to be treated with respect and with dignity in what should be an equal relationship.
In case there is any doubt that we need a new look at labour relations, let me remind the House of a few things that were and were not happening when the Woods task force was set up to look at labour relations in Canada.
Man had not yet stepped on the moon. There was no such thing as a VCR. We had never heard of AIDS or compact disks. Computers were something that occupied whole floors of buildings rather than a little comer of a
desk, and we did not know that we were destroying the environment.
We had a situation where the majority of women were not in the work force. The majority of women, especially women with young children did not even consider working. We were just a decade out of the time when if one happened to be a married woman one was not allowed to be employed in the Public Service. We certainly did not believe that people with disabilities could be employed for what they were able to do rather than unemployed and left out of the work force because of what they were not able to do.
Canada had a largely white population. It did not have an official bilingualism policy and we had a totally different work force than we have today.
In 1968 the first of the baby boomers were just hitting the work force. Everybody had a job. Anybody could get a job, virtually whatever job they wanted. That went on for nearly a decade as this huge swell of young people bom after the Second World War were entering the work force. Employers had a large number of employees from whom to choose because this expanding bulge in the population was coming into the work force.
Obviously things have changed since then. People in the work force are interested in issues that were not even put on the bargaining table 25 years ago. Women are in the work force and so child care and the issue of who is caring for the elderly and how that fits into one's working life are increasingly issues for discussions between employees and their employers.
There is the question of leave so that one can manage family life when two parents are in the work force at the same time. Employees in the work place, like all Canadians, are worried about how their working environment is affecting their own personal health and safety. Social attitudes have changed. It is no longer acceptable to assume that only white, middle aged males will rise to the ranks of management, that they can expect all the opportunities and rewards that the work place offers, and that women and others should be satisfied to work for a fair bit less because they are not quite as important. Those attitudes are no longer acceptable.
We are also in a changing work force. People cannot go into a job any more and expect that the same job will be there five years from now, ten years from now, and certainly not thirty years from now, as they were able to
April 27, 1992

expect a generation ago when they entered the work force. Education and training are part of what needs to be discussed in relationships between employers and their employees.
We cannot afford redundancy any more-the world is changing too fast-whether we are a private sector or a public sector employer. Functions can become redundant but we are wasteful and stupid if we allow people to become redundant.
I think it is important for the government to set the tone, to set the leadership. It is the government that is responsible for taking us into the future and for setting new directions. I think that is equally true as an employer as in any other area of policy.
There is real need for leadership here. There is real need to say that the world of the next century is a different world, that we cannot afford friction and conflict, and that the strong winning over the weak, whether it is economically or physically, is not the only way of resolving disputes.
If we look at the competitiveness and the global challenges we talk about so often in this House, the bottom line is whether Canada can meet its commitments. We cannot meet our commitments if we cannot ensure that management and labour can collaborate and co-operate to get the job done, whatever that job may be.
We can no longer afford this adversarial us and them attitude. As someone said recently before a legislative committee of this House, we need change at the top, not from the top.
The role of management, after all, is simply to facilitate the work of front-line employees. Management does not produce anything. It is simply there to assist in organizing things in a way that people on the front line can do their job: produce the automobile, grow carrots, look after children or pick up dogs on the street. Whatever the job of that employee is, the role of management is to allow that employee to do his or her work.
We can no longer have this attitude that because people are up there on the employment scale they are
Private Members' Business
somehow better and know better than those who are actually doing the work. We cannot wait until things blow up. The opportunities this country needs and our people need will be lost to us if that is the way we handle problems. It is in the best Canadian tradition for this kind of an approach to be taken when we see the need for change and see the need for collaboration in solving problems.
The Canadian tradition is that we solve problems. We do not allow them to blow up. We accommodate. We sit down and we solve differences. That is the only way. The motion proposed by my friend from Kenora-Rainy River will allow us to have a serious look at how we can have co-operative labour relationships in this country to free up people to use the best of their potential and to recognize workers as human beings who should be and want to be partners with their employer in having a good company, making a good product, delivering a good service and making this a better country.

speakeroldname: Mrs. Monique Tardif (Parliamentary Secretary to Solicitor General of Canada):

speakeroldname: Mr. David Dingwall (Cape Breton-East Richmond) moved:
speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
That, in the opinion of this House, the interests of Canadians
would be best served by an immediate federal general election.
He said: Mr. Speaker, I rise today to lead off this debate after spending some two weeks in my home riding of Cape Breton-East Richmond. All I can say is that Canadians in that region of the country are hurting. They have asked me what the Government of Canada is doing to assist people who are in need and why it does not care.
I had a hard time answering their questions. I said I did not know why this government did not care, but all I do know is that this government is quick to blame others for its troubles. It blames its own public servants. It blames provincial governments. It blames the Liberal Party of Canada. It blames Canadian business for not being competitive and it blames Canadian workers for being greedy and inefficient.
Everywhere in this great country of ours there are those who suffer from this government's misguided policies and its gross negligence. Simply put, this government is tired. This government is aimless. It has lost its direction. This government is spiritless.
It is bankrupt of people with a sense of public duty and it is bankrupt of ideas. For the past three and a half years this Conservative administration has interpreted the results of the last election in a narrow manner and has used its majority to force ill-considered views and policies on the people of Canada.
Based on a steady downward trend in the polls, we can see why the government is totally paralysed in attempting to cope with the results of its own policies. Perhaps that is why the Prime Minister contemplated abandoning his government's sinking ship to become Secretary-General of the United Nations.
The essence of democratic government is that governors govern with the consent of the governed. The
mandate concept of parliamentary government is a distortion of the principles of parliamentary democracy. When the people elect a Parliament they do not intend to elect a five-year dictatorship. Those who command a majority in the House of Commons have not received a licence to do whatever they want whenever they want.
Depending on the issues debated in the election campaign, those who command that majority may claim to have the permission of the electorate to take certain initiatives, but they have no claim, no claim at all, in being free to follow policies that are both of questionable wisdom and unquestionably unacceptable.
If the present government can lay claim to having received a mandate in the election of 1988, it was a mandate that was abused. It was a mandate that was limited in scope and a mandate that has long since expired. It was a mandate obtained under false pretences, a mandate that disintegrated in the face of political and economic reality.
That is why the opposition has brought before the House today a motion calling upon the Government of Canada to call an immediate election.
In the limited time given to me today I want to examine some of the record of the Progressive Conservative Party during the last eight years.
In 1988 the government sold free trade to Canadians as the wonder drug for the ills of the Canadian economy. It promised unlimited access to a market of 250 million consumers and it promised an agreement that would make Canadians immune to American protectionism.
Speaking in this House on December 22, 1988, the right hon. Prime Minister said that under a free trade agreement:
We will have a genuine shield against U.S. protectionism, whether
from the Congress or the administration.
Strong words indeed but meaningless for the workers at Moosehead Breweries who were laid off last week because of the threatened U.S. duties on Canadian beer.
But beer is not the only industry embroiled in trade disputes; softwood lumber, pork, carpets, automobiles as seen in the made-in-Canada Honda case. Now there is talk of disputes in the high-tech industries of computers. So much for the genuine shield.
April 27, 1992

Even the deputy trade negotiator, Gordon Ritchie, now sees the failings of the free trade agreement. I quote a statement made by him on December 20, 1991.
There is mounting evidence that the U.S. administration in Congress are simply unprepared to honour the spirit or in some cases, even the letter itself of the free trade agreement.
That is why, as noted in the Angus Reid poll two weeks ago, 69 per cent of Canadians want to renegotiate the free trade deal. That is the position of the Leader of the Liberal Party of Canada who has made that statement in the House as well as outside the House.
The workers should be asked whether or not they want to have this free trade deal renegotiated. We should ask the workers of Amco Petroleum in Calgary, Alberta or the workers of Cambridge Footwear in Cambridge, Ontario or the workers of CANFOR Plywood or, indeed, the workers in Dorion, Quebec who lost 175 jobs as a result of the free trade agreement.
In 1984 this government committed itself to a national child care program. It was promised in elections and subsequent throne speeches as late as 1991. But what did Canadians get from their majority government? They got an unfocused, inefficient child benefit package. The minister of health stated that the national day care program had been abandoned because he wanted to help abused and hungry children.
Yet for the past seven years this same government has cut back on every support for these same abandoned and hungry children, including transfer payments under the Canada Assistance Plan, health care, and now in the most recent budget, family allowances.
Not only did the minister live up to his government's promise, but on February 27, 1992 the Minister of National Health and Welfare even bragged about breaking the government's commitment, and I quote:
I have the privilege on day care, as I have had on many other issues like VIA Rail, to be the killer.
Supply
Members on the other side of the House, such as the government House leader, wonder why the public has such a low opinion of this government and of this institution.
On the issue of unemployment insurance, we find that the government has abdicated its responsibility to workers of this country by imposing Bill C-21 on a battered economy.
By reducing the benefit period to claimants, the government has created a new statistic not officially kept. This statistic is the group called exhaustees, who are found, unfortunately, in every part of this country. This group of people eventually finds itself on the welfare rolls because this government has given up on them.
This government once tried to deindex seniors' pensions. It had to retreat quickly on this initiative and one would have thought it would have learned. But once again this Tory government insulted seniors of this country by giving a 37 cent increase on their pension cheques and then travelled the country bragging about it. It will not even buy a loaf of bread, a litre of milk, a cup of coffee or even a newspaper.
I said earlier that the essence of democratic government is the consent of the people. In an election, the choice of who shall govern may be determined for the next four years, but those who are chosen are obliged throughout that time to assure that they have the consent of the people to the general direction and methods of their government.
In Canada the principal institution for the exercise of democratic obligations is the House of Commons. The House not only passes legislation but it holds government to public account. The whole democratic system is one of give and take which is designed to assure that even though there are people who view themselves as winners or losers, in any political decision, those who perceive themselves as losers in one case continue to accept the process on the premise that they have a chance the next time around to be winners.
This is not how the present government understands democracy. It sees no need to assure on a continual basis that the nation consents to their governing. It thinks that on November 21,1988 it got a renewed licence to dictate to Canadians and that it has no obligation to listen to

April 27, 1992
Supply
dissent and criticism or to ameliorate its policies in light of popular rejection.
It thinks that on November 21, 1988 the Tories and their big business patrons were the winners and the rest were losers and were to be kept that way as long as could be. This is most clearly illustrated in its attitude toward the House of Commons. Despite their majority control of the House, the Progressive Conservative administration has been so unwilling to hear criticism and dissent that in seven and one-half years in power it has used closure more than all previous governments put together.
I want to indicate to the House that under Prime Minister Borden it was used seven times, under Prime Minister Arthur Meighen once, King once, Bennett twice, St. Laurent four times, Pearson once and Trudeau six for a total of 22. The right hon. Prime Minister who happens to lead this government, 14 times it was moved, 9 notices given, some not moved for a total of 23. That has been the trademark of this government.
Since the 1988 election, the government has moved closure 16 times. In this Parliament, the government has used closure to force through the gutting of the unemployment insurance plan, the clawback of family allowances and old age pensions and to push the GST down the throats of ordinary Canadians. It even tried to use closure on the debate on the gulf war.
On several occasions, the government has used closure to suspend the rules of Parliament because they prevented it from getting its way as easily as it wanted. A little more than one year ago, it used closure to force new rules on the House that had three effects. First, it reduced the number of days each year the House sits so that there would be less opportunity to criticize the government. Second, it reduced the ability of parliamentary committees to hear witnesses from the public on the potential effects of proposed legislation. Third, it made it even easier to use closure on debates the government just happens to find inconvenient.
The government does not want to hear dissent to its actions. It does not care who stands in its way. It believes that the last election gave it licence to do anything it
wants and all that can stop it is a new election. That is why a new election is needed and needed now.
The government's budgetary record under the guidance of the former Minister of Finance was a dismal failure. The new Minister of Finance, trying to work on the mess left to him by his predecessor, had to adopt two points of the Liberal Party's emergency economic plan in the 1992 budget having to do with housing. The strong response from the housing sector has impressed even the most optimistic supporters of these measures.
While we welcome these initiatives, we maintain that over all the budget lacks a clear strategy oriented toward economic growth. In fact, the Minister of Finance admits that even he expects the current recovery to be weak by historical standards. On page 41 in the 1992 budget paper, he says and I quote: "Annual growth this year and next remains well below the 4.7 per cent average of growth in the 1983 and 1984 recovery period".
In addition to forecasting sluggish economic growth, the most recent budget also forecasts prolonged high unemployment. The Department of Finance predicts that unemployment will average 10.1 per cent for 1992 and 9.5 per cent for 1993. Once again the Minister of Finance is making overly optimistic predictions. For the vast majority of the 1.5 million people now looking for work in this country, the recession will not be over for a long, long time.
After the release of the spring review of the Conference Board of Canada, chief economist Jim Frank said: "The employment results of the past month are nothing short of disastrous".
Ibday in Canada the unemployment rate is 11.1 per cent; 1,525,000 Canadians are without work. Over 414,000 youth are unemployed for a rate of 16.9 per cent. Unemployment among young males is 19.3 per cent and for young females it is 14.3 per cent. Over 615,000 women in this country are without work for an average of 10 per cent of unemployment insurance.
The employment results of the past month are nothing short of a disaster. The facts speak for themselves.
Since Confederation the average time between federal elections has been three years and eight months. We
April 27, 1992

have now almost reached that time since the last election. Our motion calls for an immediate election.
Many who are watching this debate today may ask why we are calling for this in such a politically delicate time. It is precisely for this reason that we are calling for this action. From the beginning this government has not given leadership. This government was elected under the guise of providing choices and new policies. The people of this country, in my view, were deceived; they were promised sacred cows and all they got was bull. If we in the Official Opposition do not fight for our vision, the vision millions of Canadians have, I believe we would be irresponsible in our deliberations.
This government has lost the moral authority to govern. We must make sure that the Canadian electorate has the opportunity to give moral authority to a government with a vision and a direction for this nation of ours to grow to its fullest potential.
In this country we are threatened by a government that has no vision. We are, at this early time in our nation's history, threatened by a government that just does not care. It does not care about the economy and it does not care about the livelihood of working people. It has no vision of the future. I suggest respectfully that the people of Canada do have a vision and it is time to let the people decide.
In the words of Oliver Cromwell as he dismissed a Parliament that had outlived its usefulness, words which were also echoed by Leo Amery to an exhausted and morally bankrupt British government in May 1940:
You have sat too long for any good you have been doing. Depart,
I say, and let us have done with you. In the name of God, go.
I say to this government that its time has now come. If it is confident of its policies, if it is confident of the direction in which it believes it is taking this great country, it should afford Canadians the real opportunity by placing them before the general public and letting it decide.
The essence of democracy is the exercise of that right, the right to vote in a Canadian election. I have heard that the minister of constitutional renewal now seems to be contemplating his future, whether it be some ambassador's appointment abroad or not running in the next
Supply
election. Whatever it might be, we hear and see signs every day of a tired government bankrupt of ideas, bankrupt of caring for those who need the caring of the state. I am humbly asking on behalf of all those Canadians, the 1.5 million who are unemployed, the million or so who are on unemployment insurance and those millions of Canadians who have had to suffer the indignity of having to go on welfare, on behalf of the regions of this country who are crying out for leadership from a national government that the Government of Canada do the honourable thing, call a general election and allow the people of Canada to decide.

Mr. Speaker, after listening to the hon. member, I am reminded of what I read this morning in Jeffrey Simpson's column after he got back from a trip to Japan. When we are talking about the well-being of all Canadians I think it is very important to make sure we are talking about the right things at the right time and that the subjects we are raising are the important ones.
Earlier, in the debate that preceded this one, we heard a request for a commission of inquiry into the state of labour relations in the public service, and there were references to problems that seem quite incredible today. Opposition members seem to forget that the situation may vary from year to year and that is not necessarily what they claim it to be.
For instance, to get back to the debate we had earlier, in 1966 we had 600 strikes in Canada, compared with 460 in 1991. In 1966, 412,000 workers went on strike or were locked out, compared with 249,000 in 1991. Production time during work stoppages was three and a half days in 1966 but only one day in 1991. There always seems to be a tendency to identify major problems with a government that may have changed in the meantime. I must say I find it extremely difficult to debate issues with the opposition, because instead of looking at the facts they tend to exaggerate and to forget there are contingencies we cannot avoid, although the government is doing its best.

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has obviously made my case. The hon. member has just said that the government opposite does not want to accept responsibility for the economic mess that it got us into. What does the government do? It blames someone. If it is not provincial governments, it will be labour.
Let me give one example of how the Government of Canada has accepted responsibility for its actions. That was the strike it caused with regard to the Public Service of this country. Any government that cannot manage its own human resources surely cannot deserve the respect, the admiration or the confidence of the people of Canada to get on with building a strong economy.
I know it is quite fashionable in some circles to point to the Public Service and to point to labour as being greedy and inefficient. That is very saleable in some quarters. The fact of the matter remains that this government will not accept its responsibilities for the carnage, for the disastrous economic numbers we have with us today.
The hon. member's question is answered by her own rhetoric. I ask the hon. member why she is shifting the responsibility on to others and not accepting her own responsibility for the mess which she and her party got this country into.
The government is always quick to stand in its place and take credit for anything that may happen internationally which may have a good effect on Canada. But it is never prepared, no minister of the government opposite is ever prepared to stand in his or her place to accept the responsibilities for what they have done to cause such economic chaos and such a mess in this country.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with great interest to my hon. friend's speech this morning.
He touched on the free trade agreement. He talked about some companies that were critical of the free trade agreement, although I can name as many or more that are in praise of the free trade agreement. They support it and they will tell the hon. member that they have established here or expanded here because of the free trade agreement.
The latest is Northern Telecom in my riding which just moved quite a bit of manufacturing from the United States. That company found it was more efficient and better done in Canada and has moved all its production to Canada and is hiring.
We can name company after company. Kodak Canada established a chemical plant just recently which I had the pleasure of opening. The president of Eastman Kodak in the United States stood up and said: "Because of the free trade agreement, we established this plant here".
The hon. member can give all the examples he wants. He is extremely critical of the free trade agreement. What I want to know today is what his government, if his party ever had the opportunity to form a government, would do with the free trade agreement? What exactly is the policy of the Liberals?

speakerposition: Official Opposition House Leader; Liberal Party House Leader
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the hon. member rising in the House to pose a question. I am wondering if he has the same sort of confidence with regard to the free trade agreement now that workers at Caterpillar in his own riding have lost some jobs.

And what does he say specifically about the fact of holding a consensus on the Constitution? If the Prime Minister did what President Johnson did in the United States during the height of the division in that country over the Vietnam problem, which was very horrible, and made an announcement that he would not be involved in the succeeding election, would this itself not help per-

haps to get some consensus on the constitutional package, if the Prime Minister made such a declaration before a referendum or an election?

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not know whether I should thank my hon. colleague for his questions and particularly the preliminary remarks that he made before his questions. If the hon. member is suggesting to me and to others that we ought to make representations to the government opposite, either for the purposes of signing a petition or making additional representations to the Prime Minister to get the Prime Minister to resign or to announce that he will not run again in the next federal election, that this somehow may have a positive effect in terms of the constitutional discussions, I think there would be a strong argument and a strong body of thought across this country that would probably agree with the hon. member that it may be of some help to those negotiations.
Now, with regard to the whole constitutional renewal process, we do not have a clear proposal from the Government of Canada. We do not know what its agenda is. On one day there is no referendum, the next day there is a referendum, and the day after that there may not be a referendum.
So the point that I have made is that we should clear the air and give a new administration an opportunity to put in place some things that must be put in place and then we can deal quite quickly, if there is an election held soon, to get on with rebuilding the economy, and of course addressing our concerns with regard to the Canadian Constitution.

speakeroldname: Hon. John McDermid (Minister of State (Finance and Privatization)):
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate participating in the debate today. Before I get into the substance of my remarks, I just want to make a couple of comments on my friend's responses to my question.
He first of all mentioned the Caterpillar company in my constituency. Indeed, unfortunately, Caterpillar closed down in Brampton and moved its operations back to the United States. The president of Caterpillar stood up and made it very clear that the free trade agreement helped Caterpillar in Brampton. It removed the tariff on the equipment that it was producing there to be shipped to the United States.

April 27, 1992
Supply
The one thing that my hon. friend forgot to mention in his comments, and which unfortunately the decision was based on, was two major strikes by the CAW in a matter of two years which were lengthy, which were nasty, and which unfortunately the company could no longer tolerate. Therefore, we lost that business in Brampton, unfortunately. I say unfortunately because that was the reason.
Now we have just recently seen the same thing happen in the United States to Caterpillar, by the way. In the United States it got an agreement with its workers, but it got it the hard way, the tough way, and it was not a pleasant situation.
So, I feel as badly as the hon. member does about losing that industry in my community. But to blame it on the free trade agreement is totally erroneous.
The second thing he talks about is the disputes we have with the United States in trade agreements. Now let us put this in context. Our trade with the United States is the largest trading between any two countries in the world. If they go back and take a look at my speeches during the free trade debates they will see that nowhere did we say that there would be no more disputes. If we thought there would be no more disputes because of the free trade agreement, we would not have put in a dispute settlement mechanism.
That is one of the glories of the free trade agreement. We have that mechanism now. Disputes will arise. When you have the largest trading partnership in the world, of course you are going to have disputes. That is only natural. We now have a method to solve those disputes and that is what is so very important.
The second thing he raised was beer. He brought up the problem with beer trade between the United States and Canada. Heavens, we have problems with beer trade between provinces in this country; we cannot trade beer between provinces, let alone between Canada and the United States.
I might remind the House and hon. members that this was a GATT decision. The GATT found that Canada was using unfair practices in the sale of beer and imported beer. That decision was made some time ago, and Canada has been delaying for some time the change in marketing procedures. The United States had had
enough. It said that the GATT had ruled and had found Canada wrong.
What we in Canada were trying to do was negotiate a phase-in. We finally did. We finally reached an agreement that seems to be suitable to all parties.
That is how you solve these problems. You do not solve these problems by calling an election out of the blue because problems arise, certainly problems arise. Governments have mandates to work on those problems and solve them and that is exactly what we are doing.
The opposition suggests in its motion today that in the opinion of this House the interests of Canadians would be best served by an immediate federal election.
The last time the Liberals called an early provincial election, in Ontario, as I recall, they called it before their mandate was even close to being up. They were taught a lesson and we in Ontario are sorry they were taught that lesson, but they were.
They called it early. They were a little over three years into their mandate, as this government is, and they had quite a split in the vote. We in Ontario know what happened. We got an NDP government. I will let the public decide whether that was a good thing. I have my own opinions which I am sure would be of no surprise to anyone who is here in the House or watching today.
The opposition is suggesting now that a radical change in policies would be the best thing for this country; that under new management, its management, Canada's current economic difficulties would be solved easily and painlessly. That is what it is trying to tell the Canadian people.
It is worth noting once again that the opposition has not matched its call for change with any proposals of its own except the one I asked my friend about, the free trade agreement, and he said the opposition would renegotiate it. When you negotiate something, you are after something, but you have to be prepared to give up something if you are going to get something. That is how negotiations work.
The opposition is not telling us what it is prepared to give up. It is not prepared to tell us what it wants in return. It is saying, "elect us, trust us, and we will renegotiate it". That is all it is saying. Things simply do not work that way.
April 27, 1992

The opposition did not bring any proposals. It failed this morning to convince the Canadian people that they should have an election at this time. The reason for the failure is obvious. The opposition identifies no substantive policy alternatives because it has none, at least none that does not involve higher debt, higher taxes and higher inflation.
The only thing I have heard from the opposition to solve all our economic problems and the unemployment problems in this country is a make-work project for sewers and roads. That is it.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext: A 5 per cent RRSP premium.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
The member says a 5 per cent down payment on an RRSR The government has done that, so it is done.
My hon. friend, to his credit, is saying, "congratulations, very good". I appreciate that. That is the first bit of thanks the government has received from the opposition benches. I thank my friend from London East for those comments. I know his constituents feel the same way.
We all know there are changes Canadians are looking for. They want unemployment brought down. We want unemployment brought down. They want a return to economic growth. We all want a return to economic growth. They want interest rates to stay down. They want inflation to stay down. We know that. These are the goals our government is pursuing, the objectives that our policies, including February's budget, are designed to support. It is exactly what we are doing.
It is not just the absence of viable policy alternatives that makes today's motion invalid. First, it ignores the real driving force behind our current economic difficulties. The economic slowdown is taking place around the world and especially in the U.S., our largest export market.
My hon. friend says: "You blame it on everybody else, you don't blame it on yourself". We have been judged by those analysts around the world as following the right policies. When you produce in this country and 25 per cent of that production is shipped to the United States of America, and when one-third of your jobs rely on trade and things slow down around the world, things are going
Supply
to slow down at home. That is exactly what is happening. It is exactly what we are seeing now.
It is not surprising. It is not difficult to understand. I am sure Canadian people are not sucked in by the thought that everything that is happening here in Canada now, the high unemployment and so on, is entirely the fault of this government. Canada plays in a much bigger market than its own little island, its own little 10 provinces and 2 territories. It is up there with the big boys.
We rank 31st in population. We have the seventh or eighth largest economy in the world. We are rated by the United Nations as the most desirable country in the world in which to live-number one. If one listened to my friend this morning, one would think we are living in a Third World country. That negative talk is damaging to the psyche of the Canadian people. It is extremely damaging because we have a great country.
We have problems. God knows we have problems. We are concerned with those problems. Any member in this House, any member from any party who goes home on the weekends and meets constituents or over the last two weeks spent time in the constituency or around the country, knows we have problems. We know we have problems, and we are doing a number of things to try to alleviate some of those problems. They all take time. It is not going to happen overnight. There is no magic solution. An election is not a magic solution.
We in Canada, in going through this tough economic time, are in a very good position to come out of this economic morass we find ourselves in as the economies around the world recover.
Last week the International Monetary Fund issued its world economic outlook report and predicted Canada will record the largest economic growth of any major industrialized economy this year and in 1993. These are not spectacular numbers. I do not want to mislead the people by saying these are wonderfully huge numbers and our economy is just going to soar. They are modest numbers, but in being modest they are at the top of all industrialized economies. We are in a very good position.
I quote from the International Monetary Fund's research director at a news conference when the report was released:

More work needs to be done on the fiscal imbalance but I think one would say there is greater confidence concerning both past accomplishments and future actions than there is in several other important industrial countries and that should aid confidence and recovery in Canada.
I want to get back to what I said a little earlier by stressing the positive, by talking positively about this country. We are celebrating 125 years. Let us talk positively about what we have in this country such as our good educational system, our good health care, our good industries, our good service sector, our wonderful world-class universities, all the positive things we have in this country. We must talk about them. When I say that, I do not want to down-play the real problems we still face, because we do have them. There are too many Canadians out of work. There is anxiety about the threat of job loss by those who are working and economic confidence is low. Business confidence is up dramatically, however, and I am pleased to see that. But the solution to these problems does not lie in vague promises of change from the opposition. In particular, the solutions will not be found in the tragic formula of higher spending, higher taxes and higher deficits. We tried that before and some of the provinces are trying that now. It does not work and we know that.
Instead, the solution lies in sticking to the policies that are setting the foundation for that renewed growth as confirmed by the IMF. Our prospects for that growth will be made even stronger as Canadians recognize the positive factors we have worked hard to put in place.
Let me remind the House of some of the economic developments that demonstrate why there is good reason for renewed confidence in our economic prospects. The commercial prime bank rate is 7.75 per cent. That is a drop of 7 percentage points since May of 1990. Mortgage rates have also fallen substantially; 9 per cent on a one-year conventional mortgage compared to 14.25 per cent a mere one year and a half ago. For a $75,000 mortgage amortized at 25 years, that is a saving of $273 a month or about one-third of a family's mortgage costs.
Underlying this progress is a substantial drop in inflation. Year over year increase in the Consumer Price Index this March was 1.6 per cent. Over the last three months it has held pretty well steady at that level. That is one of the lowest levels since the early 1970s. Each of these factors represents important progress in putting a
strong foundation for renewed confidence, competitiveness and sustained growth. Lower mortgage rates, easing inflation and new house prices have improved housing affordability to one of the best levels in 10 years. That is important because that is a very important part of our economy.
We have taken further action. My friend from London East mentioned very briefly the 95 per cent insured mortgage from CMHC providing a down payment of 5 per cent, and 12,500 people have taken advantage of that in the first two months of operation and the RRSPs for a home purchase. We have not yet found out exactly how many are taking advantage of that, but I am sure those figures will be available in the not too distant future. The housing market has been responding to lower rates. I will not go into the statistics today, but needless to say there are improvements in housing. The March starts were down somewhat, but the homebuilders and CMHC are not concerned.
We need jobs in this country and the place we are going to find those jobs is in trade. In a trade dependent nation like Canada, we need to maintain and create new jobs, but it is the private sector that is going to create those jobs, not the government. As politicians, if the unemployment rate drops we take great pride and say we created it. We did not create those jobs at all. Those jobs were created by business, small business primarily, small and medium-sized business, but large businesses as well. We have to encourage them to create businesses and to grow. I am pleased to see a number of businesses starting up now. Mayor Peter Robertson of my community announced yesterday that he had been opening new businesses in Brampton at about five per week over the last period of time, ranging from employees of two to thirty-five and forty. That was good news. We are starting to see some very important activity.
We need the right atmosphere for those businesses. We need low interest rates. We need inflation down so that they can borrow and be somewhat dependent on setting prices to know that they will be competitive for the near and medium term. That is very important.
It is no accident that during this last period of time Germany and Japan have kept interest rates and inflation down. Their economic growth has been pretty good. They are into problems now for a number of reasons.
April 27, 1992

I see the Speaker is indicating that I have a very brief period of time left. Let me just conclude by talking about our exports. We hear about the free trade agreement and how it is not doing the job. Our trade is up rather dramatically. It is up 5 per cent since the free trade agreement was signed. I might also say that the surplus is about $15.5 billion. As The Globe and Mail indicated, Canada is in the early stages of an export led, productivity driven economic boom with manufacturing in the feature role. Exports to the United States are climbing; $91 billion last year. That is a climb of almost 30 per cent in four years.
Therefore we have the results of the economic policies we are following. We are reducing spending in order to cut taxes. Recovery is slower than expected, but it is slower around the world, not just here. Our major trading partners are experiencing it as well.
We have results. We are delivering. We will continue to do so. It is no wonder that when it comes to proposing policies of alternatives the silence of the opposition is deafening.

Consumer confidence is not, and I agree with him whole-heartedly that it is not. It is a problem. It is a problem everywhere, not just in this country. It is a problem in all countries where people are paying down the debt they accumulated in the eighties, in the halcyon days when spending was quite prevalent and credit was being built up.
The hon. member knows that full well. He knows the statistics on consumer credit and so on. People now are concerned. They are not out spending but rather paying down their debt or investing in RRSPs and savings. The savings of this country have gone up over the last couple of years as well. I agree with that.

April 27, 1992

The point I was trying to make in my remarks is that if people stand in this House day after day and say how terrible things are, how awful this country is-and I do not mind the government being criticized for its policies and so on and so forth-then how can that instil any confidence in the Canadian people? That is my concern. I do not mind people criticizing us because we have differences of opinion on how to achieve it. We all want to achieve the same goals; there is no question about that. We have different methods of getting there. That is what makes our political parties different.

As far as taxation is concerned, I might say to the hon. member that we have high personal tax in this country. The United States has lower personal tax but a much higher social tax than we have. When we balance them off, we are not tremendously ahead of the United States in our taxation levels when we take in the social taxation and the income taxation.
