speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I listened with interest to my hon. friend and as usual find myself disagreeing with most of what he said. However, I respect the fact that he has a right to hold those views. I do not know if he has travelled very much in Canada, because what he says is certainly not what I have been hearing.
I have a question for my hon. friend. It is fair to say that he, his colleagues and the Prime Minister have imposed on Canada what I call a corporate agenda, a Conservative agenda, and have made major changes. They have introduced a major free trade policy with the United States. They are now about to conclude one with Mexico. They have introduced the goods and services tax. I have just read through a list this morning of 33 tax increases which they presumably feel are in the best interests of the country.
I think it is fair to say that most Canadians feel their lives are certainly no better today than they were four years ago or eight years ago.
My friend has said that now is not the time for an election. His leader has indicated that four years is a good guideline and that he would respect the four-year term. I remind him of what happens when governments go beyond four years. I think of people like Mr. Vander Zalm who went the full five years and ended up as a
remark in some history book. I guess that will be his claim to fame one day. Mr. Devine in Saskatchewan was sort of obliterated from the political landscape and he waited a full five years. I remember my friends in the Liberal Party when Pierre Elliott Trudeau was Prime Minister back in 1978. He extended it to the five years and he disappeared in the next election.
If my friend does not think now is the time to call an election, when does he think would be an appropriate time to seek a mandate from the people of Canada? If it is going to be some time into the future, would he indicate what is left of the Tory agenda to impose on the people of Canada in the intervening months?

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, a lot of questions were asked there. In the Canadian government the responsibility for calling an election is the Prime Minister's and the Prime Minister's alone. I would not even pretend to speculate as to when he might call an election. That is his prerogative.
There are many scenarios that everybody, all the whiz kids in the press, are laying out these days as to when we should have one or if there should be one, and so on. However that is a decision the Prime Minister has to make. I am sure that he would be appreciative of any advice that my hon. friend might give him, within reason. I am sure he would listen to him. He may not take the advice, but I am sure he would listen to him, as he usually does. I see the hon. member slipping over and talking to the Prime Minister quite often here in the House. I am sure that he listens to what the member has to say.
I am not going to touch with a 10-foot pole whether we have an early election or a late election and so on and so forth. The hon. member who introduced the motion today said that the average period of time of a government is three years and eight months when an election was called. That was average. I want people to understand that he said "average". I was in a government in 1979 that lasted eight months and then we had another election.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext: Eight months too long.

There are actually a lot of people today who wished they had kept that government. If we take that eight months off we find that elections go after the fourth year, as we did in 1988. We were four years and some months into our mandate before the election was called.
April 27, 1992

The hon. member asked if the election would be in the future. Yes, that I can assure him; the election will be in the future.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to say to my hon. friend, the Minister of State for Finance and Privatization who has just shared his views with us that perhaps the best thing he and his government could do for the people of Canada is to follow the general rule which, as he has indicated, is to have an election every three years and eight months on average. That would put it at about July 1. I could tell him that the people of Canada would not be happier to celebrate the 125th birthday of Canada on July 1 than to have the Prime Minister call an election to allow them to decide on the future of the Mulroney government. I think that would be a wonderful present for the people of Canada.
As my hon. friend suggests, perhaps I will slip over later and have a chat with the Prime Minister and give him a great suggestion in terms of how he can respond to the wishes of the people of Canada, perhaps in his case, for the very first time since 1984.
I want to begin my comments by saying that I am trying to reflect on the way the country is today, and why.
I decided to look up the definition of what a Tory is. What is a Progressive Conservative? I went to Webster's Dictionary, which says that the origin of the term Tory originally was given to those in the 16th century who plundered people in the bogs of Ireland. They were lawless in their behaviour. They were rogues. They were bandits. They were robbers. They were outlaws.
What an appropriate name for the present political party that is leading the country; robbers, outlaws, bandits, rogues and people who plunder others. The government has lived up to its historic name. I would suggest that more people in Canada would agree that if you are going to look at the behaviour of the present government, those terms would certainly describe its behaviour in the way it treated the average Canadian family.
Not long ago, Canadians had a very positive view of their country, of their lives and of their future. Canadians shared a vision and that vision was very simple. It existed until very recently. People felt that if you worked
Supply
hard and generally followed the rules and so on, you would be rewarded for that, your life would be better economically and in other ways, and your children's future would likely be better than yours.
That has been the Canadian dream year after year, generation after generation. Most of us in the House when we reflect back to our own family backgrounds would recognize that was the world of our parents. They worked hard and they knew that they worked hard. They followed the rule that their lives would be better than in the past and that their children's lives would be better than their lives.
That Canadian dream has now turned into a nightmare because of this Tory government. I would not say that this is the only reason. It is fair to say that we do live in a global community, but by and large, as others have indicated, much of what we face economically in Canada today is a result of the fallout of this government's policies.
That dream of having a better life, of being able to afford your own home, of being able to start your own business or run your own farm or ranch is gone for more and more Canadians every day. It is disappearing.
We have all been in our constituencies in the last little while. People came to me and said their kids cannot afford to go to college. They cannot afford to go to university. Some said they have not worked for six months or a year and for many people it is a lot worse than that: "My three children are having difficulty affording school".
What does that mean? We know today that what you earn in the future is what you learn today. Without being able to learn today, your earning power is going to be reduced.
What has led to this nightmare? What has led to the fact that the Canadian dream that we have known now for our entire history has been shattered by this government? What has changed?
I believe that if we trace the origins of this collapse of the Canadian dream, we would find that it is a result of this government's policies. We can basically summarize them as a set of corporate policies. It is a corporate agenda set on Bay Street or Wall Street or Kabuto Cho

April 27, 1992
Supply
Street in Tokyo; in other words, set on the main business avenues. This government's policies are built around the notion that what is good for General Motors is good for the country and good for Canadians.
Most Canadians do not believe that, but this government does. It has introduced, with its industrial, economic, fiscal, monetary and tax policies specifically, the notion that if you give the wealthy corporations benefits, if you give the wealthy people of Canada benefits, they will spend their money and invest and the results will eventually get down to the regular folks. This is called the trickle down theory.
People are sick of being trickled on by this government and its policies. We are sick of it, and people are fed up with the notion that they have been trickled on and trickled on. It has become clear that these policies are not working for Canadians. The policies of this government are not working for Canadian families.
We are now, regardless of whether the government is prepared to admit it or not, in a form of economic gridlock. The country is simply not moving. We do not find expansion in the farm community. We do not find enthusiastic expansion in the small business community, in the industrial community or in the resource community. One would have to look very hard to find much encouragement at all in terms of what is going on in the Canadian economy.
As my friend indicated earlier, the level of investor, entrepreneurial and consumer confidence is low because people do not trust this Prime Minister and his government.
Look at the statistics. I am not going to bore the House with a long list of statistics today. Let us go back to November 21, 1988 when this government took over and compare it to November 1991 from which we have good statistics. Unemployment for example in November when the government was elected was 1 million; now it is 1.4 million. Manufacturing jobs were 2.13 million; today they are 1.48 million, a significant drop. Business bankruptcies in 1988 were running at 7,721 annually; in the first 10 months of last year they were up to over 11,000. Consumer bankruptcies were 26,000 in 1988; in 1991 they were already for the first 10 months at 52,000. Housing
starts when the government was last elected were 222,000; this past year they were 152,000.
Look at the deficit. The deficit was the great reason the government introduced these policies. Therefore, one would assume that the deficit has gone down. In 1985, the deficit was $30.6 billion. This past year it was $31.4 billion, and probably when the facts come in it will be a lot higher. TTie debt, when the Conservatives took over back in 1984, was less than $200 billion. Today it is in excess of $400 billion and climbing.
Is it any wonder that the people of Canada do not trust this government and do not trust the Prime Minister when they say they are acting in our best interest? People know dam well that they are not. I remember in this House not long ago the Prime Minister stood up and said that before the next general election we will have a comprehensive national child care policy in place. Then his minister recently said he has decided to kill that program. He killed VIA Rail before that and he killed the Katimavik program and now he has said that he would kill the national child care program.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext: Killed VIA Rail? It's finally making a profit.

Now my Tory friends are asking about VIA Rail. They should come to western Canada where communities that were once served by VIA Rail do not have VIA Rail, period. They should come to Atlantic Canada and central Canada where communities that had VIA Rail service for years and years do not have any service at all.
Let us talk about the adjustment program. When the free trade agreement was brought in the Prime Minister said: "We know there will be jobs lost, that people will have their jobs disappear and there will be major dislocations. We are going to introduce an adjustment program that will be among the most generous brought forward anywhere in the world". We are still waiting for that adjustment program. Tens of thousands of Canadians are waiting for that adjustment program. It is simply not there. It was another fabrication.
I could go on and on. I have lists here of broken promises, one after the other. Let us talk about the biggest promise of all. The Conservatives were elected, they said, in the last election to go ahead with this free
April 27, 1992

trade agreement with the United States. It became very clear that they did not have the majority of Canadians supporting it they thought they had and they therefore imposed it using the most Draconian parliamentary tactics we have ever seen in the House. They imposed the free trade agreement with the United States.
The result was that the Prime Minister said: "If we do this, what we are doing is not popular but it is right". He meant right wing. It catered to the right agenda in that sort of father knows best approach to government: "I know that Canadians do not understand what we are doing, but what we are doing is the right thing and they will realize this later".
Since that free trade agreement has been signed, we have lost in excess of 200,000 manufacturing jobs alone and they are gone permanently.
I could go on and on, tens of thousands of jobs gone, gone, gone. The corporate presidents make their announcements: "Yes, we are closing down our plant in Ontario and we are moving our plant down to North Carolina. We are closing our plant in Quebec and moving it down to Tennessee. We are closing our plants here right across the country and moving them down to the southern states or Mexico". Now the government says: "Listen, if you thought free trade with the United States was a great idea, we have an even better one. We are now going to sign one with Mexico".
I have just come back from Mexico. I spend three days in the Maquiladora zone, going through various plants, talking to the workers. I asked what the average pay was. I found that some plants paid 40 cents an hour and others paid up to $2 an hour, but the average was 92 cents in all the plants I toured. The average age of the employees in the plants I toured was 18. This is the idea of the level playing field this government wants. It wants us to compete on a level playing field with businesses that pay 92 cents an hour, that exploit their workers and ignore the environment.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I appreciate your intervention. I have obviously touched a nerve with my colleagues over there.
Let us talk about leadership. In a democracy it has been commonly assumed that the leader of the country listens to the people and then carries on and introduces policies that reflect their goals and aspirations and so on. By asking Canadians across the country, we find that the rating and public esteem held by our Prime Minister is the lowest it has ever been in Canadian history. No Prime Minister has been held in contempt like this Prime Minister has been .His party is literally out of the picture. The Prime Minister and his party have the lowest public support in Canadian history. They have abandoned the people of Canada. They have not listened. We have a government that is directionless, there is no leader.
It reminds us of the old story by Robert Louis Stevenson called "The Wreckers". The wreckers were unscrupulous types along the rocky beaches of an island. They built huge bonfires at night so that ships laden with goods would see them and think they were lighthouses and as they approached the beach would hit the rocks and their contents would be then plundered by those unscrupulous types on shore. That is what this government is doing. Robert Louis Stevenson was describing the Prime Minister and his cabinet. They are destroying the Canadian economy.
My friends opposite should talk to their constituents and ask them if their lives are better today than they were five or six years ago. Is their confidence in their future and their children's future better than it was? Do they have hopes and aspirations for their children that are greater today than they were five or six years ago? The answers to all of those questions would be no.
There is a sense that this government is taking us down a suicidal course, economically, socially, culturally and politically; that what is good for George Bush and his Republicans in Washington is good for Canadians through our Prime Minister and his Conservative government. They are both the same. They have the same vision of the future.

April 27, 1992
Supply
Now it is tax time. Canadians have been filling out their tax returns in the last few weeks and there are only another couple of days to go. We are all reminded of what the Conservative government has done to us.
I have a list here that I was going to read into the record but it is so dismal, it is so disheartening, it is so sad that I do not think I will. I have 33 examples of how the Conservative government has increased taxes on working Canadian families since it has been in office, 33 different tax measures. I am not going to read them. If people are interested they will certainly be able to see them.
It is not simply the taxes that are imposed on the people of Canada, it is the unfair nature of the taxation. Canadians do not mind paying taxes as long as they are getting a good return. They realize that a lot of people are not paying taxes. Wealthy people are able to use a whole set of loopholes and the statistics are all here by Statistics Canada. They are able to use the loopholes and not pay any income tax.
The Minister of State for Finance knows that in some years the banks in Canada, which are the most prosperous sector of our country, because of the tax loopholes in the system, do not pay any income tax at all. The teller pays income tax, the accountant pays income tax and the people cleaning the bank pay income tax, but the bank itself, in spite of the fact that it is making hundreds of millions of dollars in profits, pays no income tax in many years.
When the Royal Bank of Canada or the Bank of Montreal or the Imperial Bank of Commerce, pick your bank, in some years paid no income tax at all in spite of the fact that they make hundreds of millions of dollars in profits, and the teller, the cleaning lady and the person running the parking lot pay taxes, then we say there is something wrong with that tax system and Canadians know that.
Some of the best sellers at this time of the year in any book store are the books on how to use all the loopholes to avoid paying taxes or to defer paying taxes. These books are the best sellers. Good accountants and tax lawyers write the books and they are the tax advisors. They say there is a myriad of ways that you can avoid paying taxes.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext: If you have money.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
It is not by doing anything illegal, but by taking advantage of what this government and subsequent Liberal governments have brought in to allow people to defer paying taxes.
I look at one here, for example, the capital gains matter. In other words, if you make certain amounts of money on capital gains you do not pay taxes or you pay at a much lower rate. Is that right? In the United States you do not get away with that. In the world of Ronald Reagan or George Bush they say that when you make money on capital gains you pay taxes on them, but this government says that you do not have to pay taxes on certain capital gains.
People know that this government has introduced and maintains a very distorted tax system, a very convoluted tax system, a very complex tax system to allow certain people to take advantage of it, which they do. We all know examples of this and we could repeat them at some length. For the average working person, the average working family, there are no loopholes, there are no tax exemption programs. They pay through the nose. They know that they are paying more than their fair share. They know they are paying more than they should. That is why there is a whole growing underground economy today as people seek ways and means of avoiding paying into what they perceive to be a very unfair tax system.
It is fair to say that if there was ever a time to call an election it is now. People feel that we are like a rudderless ship, that the country is going nowhere. Some people are benefiting. Some large corporations are benefiting, but for the average working family, for the average small business owner, for the average farmer, things are not getting any better and for many they are getting a lot worse. There is no sense that we are going to change course. There is no sense of a new direction.
We hear the Minister of Finance, the Minister of International Trade, the Prime Minister and others saying: "Yes we have confidence. We are going to continue on here as we have been."
Canadians want a change. They want to deviate. They want to move into a more progressive era with policies that reflect their benefit and their families' concerns. I remember the Prime Minister standing up and saying that he was going to wage this great war on drugs in this country and do all these things to counter drug use and abuse in the country. I am looking very hard and I do not find much evidence of this in communities across the country. I do not see that there was a serious effort on behalf of the government.
April 27, 1992

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext: Literacy.

speechtext:
There is the literacy issue. We can go on and on, but my time does not permit it.
Let me simply summarize by saying this. I listened carefully to my hon. friend, the Minister of State for Finance. I listened to his comments describing what this government has done for the people of Canada. It tells it all. Listening to him, to what he had to say, listening to the government's agenda that is being introduced and continues to be introduced, is the best reason to call an election today to let the people of Canada decide what kind of a government they want, which will certainly be a government that is different from this one.

speakeroldname: Mr. Benno Friesen (Parliamentary Secretary to Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Secretary of State for External Affairs
subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the House leader for the New Democratic Party has probably been the most frequent and outspoken critic of the government over the past few years. Usually it has been on themes such as patronage when he would talk about hacks, flacks, and bagmen. It is always from the exalted position with the inference that "we would never do that"; the pure socialists who have never been in federal office are pure because they have never been in office.
He started his speech by saying it would be good to have an election on July 1. The people of Canada would welcome that. I suspect that the people of Ontario would welcome it if the premier of Ontario would call an election for July 1. They would be just as happy as the member suggests others might be for a federal election.

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I feel privileged to have the opportunity to participate in this debate.
Before I came to the House today, I tracked down some work that was done by an economist by the name of Tom McCormack who has a company in Oakville, Ontario, called Strategic Projections. I am sure that many members of the government have heard of Mr. McCormack because, quite frankly, most of his work basically agrees with the thrust that the government has been taking.
I recommend his paper to all members in the House. It talks about how we are going from recession to expansion. It is a very thorough paper. This particular paper is weighted to Ontario, but it gives a pretty good sense of some of the things that are happening in the various sectors, not just in the last few years but going back for the last 10.
In fact, he makes the argument in this paper that this recession is not as bad as the recession that we had in 1991-92. You might think if it is not as bad, what is the problem that we are having in pulling ourselves out of this recession if we do not have the same depth or the same distance to come from.
Supply
I reiterated some of his points when I questioned the Minister of State for Finance earlier about the fact that today we have the lowest inflation rate in over 20 years. It is near zero.
We have interest rates that are the lowest they have been in 21 years. In spite of the monetary policy of this country, which has driven these numbers to what they are, in spite of what the Canadian people have gone through, in spite of the economic pain that Canadians have gone through, instead of at the end of this period looking forward to an expansionist mood or a positive attitude, I have never seen and I think most members of Parliament have never seen the confidence of the nation so low.
We have a genuine crisis in the confidence of people in this country. I have absolutely no doubt in my mind that the only reason why the government is spending $15 million starting today on a campaign called "We Can Do It" is because it recognizes that it does have a serious problem with consumer confidence in this country.
As members said earlier today, we have been in our constituency offices for the last two weeks listening to Canadians. I remind members of the government that our responsibility as opposition members is not to come back here and just talk about the fact that the inflation rate and interest rates are low. Our responsibility is to also bring to the government's attention some of the real problems that are out there.
One of the real problems that we have in this country right now is the fact that close to 3 million people are not working. There may only be 1.5 million on unemployment insurance, which is an awful number, but you also have to take into account the number of people on welfare. Close to 3 million people in this country right now are not working and that is the bottom line.
The Minister of State for Finance suggested in his remarks earlier today that opposition members were part of the problem because we were being negative. I do not think in any way, shape, or form it is being negative by bringing to the floor of this House the concerns of the people who are not working, the concerns of the people who are losing their homes, the concerns of people who are losing their businesses and their farms. That is our responsibility.

April 27, 1992
Supply
The other thing the government is always saying to us is that we are not putting forward ideas on this side of the House. We have been putting forward ideas for the last year. We have been putting forward ideas in a constructive way. We have talked on many occasions about "The work for tomorrow: Employment Opportunities for the '80s" that was done in this House many years ago. There were close to 185 ideas that all members of this House worked on, ideas that would put Canadians back to work. Many of these ideas would not cost the treasury of Canada a lot of money. Many of these ideas have to do with training. They have to do with giving those Canadians in our country who are suffering from illiteracy an environment so they can be retrained. It seems to me we are not advancing on a lot of the ideas that are being put forward.
I had a group come to my office just last week called Soma Film and Video company, a young entrepreneurial couple who have been award winning. They have developed ideas: "You are out of a job. Now what?" They have put forward repeatedly to various levels of government how through film and video they can put ideas into the marketplace on how people can be retrained, how they can get back into the work force, how they can maybe move from one sector, if the manufacturing sector is falling off, into a service sector. These are young entrepreneurs trying to access to their government, trying to get help, and these are the kinds of people who will help others get back to work. They are constantly being frustrated. That is one of the problems we have.
It seems when times are going well, the people of Canada do not really need as much support from this House, but when times are as tough as they are right now they count on us to accelerate those ideas through the system that will put people back to work. It seems to me this government is so possessed by its one-track mind of inflation and interest rate reduction it has gone overboard on it.
We know for every drop in the interest rate there is close to $1.4 billion saved in terms of the deficit reduction requirement of this country. Why can we not take some of that room picked up on the interest rate reduction and the inflation rate reduction and throw it at the entrepreneurship that is out there trying to create new jobs? Why not review the tax design in this country?
There are very few instruments left to mobilize the spirit or galvanize the will of this country.
The government is way ahead on inflation numbers and way ahead on interest rate numbers. Why not take some of that and use it to get the entrepreneurship of this country moving again?
Two weeks ago in my riding I spoke to a small group of businessmen. I asked how their banks were treating them. I heard conflicting signals. I went to the Minister for International Trade before the House recessed. I said: "Mr. Minister, the cartels of banking institutions in this country are being very tough on small and medium size businesses". He said: "Not so, that is not the case". I could not find one person in the two weeks I was in my riding who felt that their bankers were really treating them fairly. In fact many of them felt their banks were being overly aggressive in reducing their credit lines and cutting them back.
For example, could you imagine the bankers shutting down the Reichmanns? Can you imagine what would happen? There would be an outrage. The Reichmanns, and I say this with all due respect to their entrepreneurial spirit, do not create as many jobs as the 1,700,000 entrepreneurs that exist in this country. What do we do to get the banking institutions to pay a little bit more attention to that group within our country?
I have said in the House before that if every entrepreneur in this country were to go out and hire one person over the next 60 days, it would be a much better country. We are positioned in terms of interest rates and in terms of inflation. It is now up to them to lead. My colleague from Cape Breton-East Richmond is so right. If you are going to stay rigid in your ways then call an election; let us go to the people and let the people decide. Let the people decide if the direction you are taking this country in is the right direction.
I happen to believe that most Canadians are tired of just following everything that is done in the United States. This is one of the most creative countries in the world. We create, we design, we manufacture products that are world class. Right now, the manufacturing and the creativity of this country is practically frozen. People are working from pay cheque to pay cheque, payroll to payroll, quarter to quarter. It is a desperate situation. We have to do something to take advantage of the suffering that the people of Canada have gone through in the last
April 27, 1992

two years. We have suffered long enough. There is no reason for it to continue.
What Canadians are looking for is leadership, not only from this House but leadership from business and the media. I remember during the last election when the government wanted its business friends to advance its position on free trade, it took out full-page business ads promoting the merits of free trade.
Where are those same businessmen today? Why do they not buy full-page ads today to help pump up the marketplace, if it is as good as the Minister of State for Finance says it is? He mentioned earlier in his speech that business confidence is returning. Why do they not buy those same full-page ads today that they did during the free trade debate? It is the same thing with the national media.
The national media are probably as divisive as anyone when it comes to the spirit that exists in this country today. When you open a newspaper today, look at a television show or listen to a radio show, it is constant bad news. There is a responsibility for the national media to try and promote some of the good things that are going on out there. It is only when we have a feeling of confidence in this country that people who have resources will start hiring again and start firing up this economy. This government cannot lead. Obviously it is showing that it cannot lead. I concur with the member for Cape Breton-East Richmond that the government should call an election, go to the people and let them decide. The way things are going right now the damage in every sector of this economy is becoming so much a part of the psyche of this nation that it is going to take us years and years to recover. There is no necessity for it lasting as long as it has.

Mr. Speaker, I would say to the member that we had this discussion in this House about three months ago. How much more pain do you want to exacerbate in this Canadian economy?
The bottom line is that you do not seem to accept the fact that there is enough room in this economy right now to relieve some of the pain. You have done absolutely nothing in the last 90 days in terms of tax reform or new tax designs. You have done nothing to shake the financial institutions, to ask them to become a little more progressive in the way they are handling small and mediumsized entrepreneurs.
If you really wanted to, you probably could have already turned this economy around in the last 60 days. You knew 90 days ago what the inflation numbers were going to be. You are working on models and projections. The point is that you keep dragging it out.
The Canadian people are saying: "We have endured enough pain. There are enough people unemployed. Our tax burden is crushing us. Our creativity is being stifled. All we are doing is following the United States. We are not leading on our own. We want to get our own

policy going here and right now all we are doing is reacting to our neighbours to the south".
In answer to your question, this is not politics. We are playing with lives here. People are getting stressed out. This is an incredible strain on our health care system across the country. But there is absolutely no sense in the proposition his party has put before the House today. Here is this country at the crossroads of its history in terms of the constitutional situation and they are saying: "Create uncertainty by calling an election".
It is well known that the mandate of a government runs five years. It is common practice with a majority government that it goes four to four and a half years and then an election is called. Instead, he and his colleagues are saying: "Throw the country into uncertainty now. Let us have an election. For eight weeks let us have uncertainty."
The member talks about the economic situation and suggests that within three months this recession could have been overcome by the government. I listened to what he and his colleagues have been saying to us and what they are saying is to go out and spend money. That is what got this country in a mess in the first place. It was the profligate spending of the government of his party not so very long ago. I am appalled to hear that suggestion.
I have a question for him. The member says: "Don't pay any mind and talk about what is going on in the United States". Twenty-five per cent of the production of this country is exported to the United States. I would like my hon. friend to explain to me, given the fact that there is a recession throughout the western world, how
he expects action in this country alone to resolve that recession?

Mr. Speaker, I do not want to compete on the voice level, but I do want to say that if we changed this government then most of the uncertainty would be removed. This government has enshrined uncertainty.

But at what expense? That is the point you do not seem to be hearing. There are close to three million people out there who are not working and are losing their dignity and their homes. Canso): Mr. Speaker, I just want to make a brief reply more to the remark by my colleague from the South Shore. He mentioned the report of the IMF. I would encourage him to read the editorial today in the Halifax Daily News which comments on that very report.

But the fact of the matter is that the base from which that growth is coming is far lower. That is why our growth will be more positive than the other G-7 countries. It is because Canada's recession has been deeper
April 27, 1992

and longer than all of the other industrialized countries that report compares them with.
That is also in the report but conveniently the Minister of Finance and the Prime Minister have chosen to ignore the full contents of the report, which is that Canada's growth is expected to be higher precisely because its recession was that much deeper than all of the other countries in the industrialized world.

Mr. Speaker, the Canada Elections Act prohibits inmates serving sentences in federal penitentiaries and in provincial jails from voting. This is as it should be.
I was very disturbed when the Federal Court of Appeal and the Ontario Court of Appeal said that this restriction was unconstitutional. I am glad to see the Department of Justice is seeking to appeal these decisions to the Supreme Court of Canada.
I agree with the federal lawyers that taking the vote away from prisoners is justified in a free and democratic society. By breaking the law, individuals have broken the social contract they have with society. It is only appropriate that they surrender their privileges within society during their incarceration.
The vote should not be extended to prisoners.

Mr. Speaker, during the Easter adjournment an important agreement was reached concerning the reorganization and restructuring of Algoma Steel Corporation in Sault Ste. Marie.
Only a year ago the company faced bankruptcy, thousands of workers faced the loss of their jobs, and the city faced the loss of its principal industry and employer.
The agreement comes with considerable costs in terms of jobs and wages for the workers and heavy losses as well for investors and shareholders. However, compared to the situation facing the steelworkers and the community only a year ago this agreement is infinitely better.
Employee ownership provides an incentive to ensure the company is competitive and viable in the years ahead.
The community of Sault Ste. Marie has rallied behind the steelworkers and the company by establishing the Community Action Team to support their negotiations, securing over 20,000 members and making strong representation last fall to both levels of government.
The real challenge begins now for workers and management alike to make the restructured new Algoma Steel a viable and dynamic steelmaker, able to compete in the markets of the world.
We congratulate all those involved in this agreement and wish them well in the years ahead.

Mr. Speaker, last week I was privileged to visit Delaney Street in San Francisco. No, Delaney Street is not a street. It is a housing project built and operated by its residents without one cent of taxpayers' money. The residents are former drug addicts and convicts who come to Delaney Street either directly out of San Quentin penitentiary or right off the street. They, the residents, performing 95 per cent of the work themselves with little professional outside help, have built a magnificent triangular shaped home for 500 men and women. It is financed entirely by a number of small businesses operated by the residents themselves.
If we are ever going to house the 1.2 million low income Canadians who cannot afford to house themselves, our non-profit and co-op housing resource groups, who are understandably concerned about reductions in government funding for assisted housing, must start to adopt the Delaney Street model.

Mr. Speaker, today the Minister of National Revenue announced changes to the GST aimed at simplifying the tax for small businesses.
This is not the first time the government has tried to make it easier for businesses to pay their taxes. Even the minister admits that the past 16 months of GST have been a learning experience for the department.
Some reports claim that it has cost billions to collect the GST. Businesses have had nothing but trouble trying to figure out how to comply with the tax.
The government must learn that you cannot make a bad tax a good tax no matter how much fine-tuning you do with it. After 16 months of this oppressive tax, the government has realized that small businesses are confused by its complexity.
The government should realize that even if Canadians may be confused by the tax itself, they are not confused by who has forced this tax on us. The government maybe slow learners, but Canadians will teach them a hard lesson before another 16 months of GST have gone by.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, in 1867, two groups, one French-speaking and one English-speaking, decided, despite their differences, to join their destinies by freely signing the British North America Act. A new country was bom: Canada.
What daring, courage and vision Sir Georges-Etienne Cartier and Sir John Alexander Macdonald had in uniting on a new territory and in a new world what the English Channel had always separated.

April 27, 1992
Enriched by the presence of native people and new arrivals, this country, which is only 125 years old, is first in the world when it comes to quality of life.
In this short time, through our common efforts, our open-mindedness, our search for compromise, balance, tolerance and justice, we have attained first place among all the nations of the world. The ultimate goal is now to remain on top.
Let us pay tribute to the founders of this country, to our Prime Minister who tirelessly defends this quality of life and let us unanimously hail those Canadians who want to build rather than destroy.

Mr. Speaker, on behalf of this House I wish to congratulate the Canadian women's ice hockey team who yesterday won an impressive 8-0 victory over Team U.S.A. in Tampere, Finland to win the 1992 Women's World Championship.
Team Canada finished the round robin section of the tournament undefeated and out-scored the opposition 38 to 3. Other teams participating at the championships included Sweden, Finland, Norway, Denmark, Switzerland and China.
The victory marks Canada's second straight women's world ice hockey title. Canada previously won the inaugural world championships in 1990.
To the players and the coaches of Canada's newest world champions we offer our congratulations and appreciation for the excellent manner in which they played and represented our country.

Today marks the beginning of National Consumer Week. The theme of this year's National Consumer Week is It's Everybody's Business.
It focuses on generating public interest in marketplace issues. The theme also highlights the important role consumers, educators, businesses and government play in addressing marketplace issues.
It is an invitation to all Canadians to collaborate in order to maintain a fair and efficient marketplace.
National Consumer Week will provide Canadians with an opportunity to become better informed on marketplace issues that concern them, as well as their own rights and responsibilities in the marketplace.

Mr. Speaker, five years ago today, on April 27,1987, a United Nations report called Our Common Future was released urging the world's governments to work together to preserve and protect our ailing environment.
This report, known commonly as the Brundtland report, urged the heads of nations at the United Nations to hold a global conference to find a common strategy to put the world on the path to sustainable development.
In just over a month the world community will try to meet this challenge and hold the largest international conference ever in an attempt to reverse the momentum leading the world to environmental destruction.
While the major stumbling block to success at Brazil '92 appears to be U.S. President George Bush, Canada has a major role to play. President Bush has not acknowledged that the planet's survival depends on our understanding of the fragile connections between the global resources and the economic policies of nations.
Canada must accept this principle and use its influence with the President to achieve success in Brazil.

Mr. Speaker, this year marks the 77th anniversary of the Armenian genocide of 1915. The systematic execution of the Armenian people of Tbrkey began on April 24, 1915 and claimed 1.5 million lives. The Armenian genocide was an intolerable state-engineered
April 27, 1992

slaughter of a people. People, organizations and governments around the world are becoming more aware of the details of the destruction of the Armenian people and are lending sympathy, understanding and support.
We must continue working together to ease the nightmares of the survivors of the genocide and teach the younger generation the importance of remembering this terrible and chilling mass extermination.
In closing, I call upon the Government of Canada to officially recognize the genocide of 1915.

Mr. Speaker, the question is: Is this government, through its fiscal and monetary agenda, doing what is right for Canada? The answer is no.
Privileged as I am to bring Hamilton to Ottawa and not the reverse, I am duty bound to report the findings of a 110 page marketing study by six McMaster University third year commerce students. The three-month study, contracted by yours truly, surveyed 222 people from all corners of Hamilton in a non-partisan fashion, including 55 business owners and managers.
The survey highlighted the fact that 36 per cent of employees surveyed are worried about losing their jobs; 52 per cent of business people surveyed believe they will lay off staff this year.
Among the recommendations; the government ought to be spending more money on such things as infrastructure and improving Hamilton airport.
In conclusion, Canadians love their country but worry about this government's shortcomings. The bottom line, it is time we had an election.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister. In the last two weeks, all hon. members, I am sure, visited their constituencies and discussed the situation in the country. Obviously there is an economic crisis and especially a crisis of confidence in the future of our country. With an unemployment rate rising every day, a rate that is over 11 per cent nationally, it is very hard for Canadians to have confidence in the country's future.
With unemployment rising daily and the number of people using food banks, what is the government prepared to do to improve the situation and give Canadians confidence?
April 27, 1992

Mr. Speaker, the New Democratic Leader surprises me with her question. She talks about gloom and worry in the land, while the International Monetary Fund has just said that this year and next, Canada will lead the world in economic growth and in job creation and have the lowest inflation of all industrialized countries. That is encouraging. I see that the New Democrats' leader has trouble taking good news, but that is very good news for job creation and for the whole country.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister. Like many Canadians I would like to hear good news, but we cannot ignore the fact that even when it is not in the headlines the rate of unemployment in this country is for most Canadians not just a recession but a depression.
I would cite for the Prime Minister several examples of the desperation that people are feeling in this country. Just last week 290 people applied for one single job at $6.50 an hour in Kingston. In another town in Ontario, Napanee, 2,700 people applied for 130 jobs. In Quebec it is reported that some 34,000 people applied for 135 jobs with the provincial auto insurance program there.
I want to ask the Prime Minister when this government is going to abandon its policy of creating unemployment and invest in the Canadian people so that we can become the competitive country he speaks about so often and get Canada back working.

Mr. Speaker, I have to tell my hon. friend, with respect, that her question perplexes me no less in English than it does in French.
In point of fact, the reports published by the IMF world economic outlook indicate that Canada is going to lead the industrialized world this year and next in economic growth, in employment growth and in low
Oral Questions
inflation. We will have the lowest inflation in the industrialized world.
The combination of these factors indicate that the fundamentals are in place for what we hope will be an impressive and durable economic recovery.
My hon. friend from the Liberal Party says: "What about employment?" He is quite right. Even though we are encouraged by the fact that employment growth in Canada will be 1.8 per cent next year and 3.1 per cent in 1993, namely the best in the world, the fact of the matter is that there are too many unemployed in Canada today.
When this government was sworn in, taking over from the Liberals, unemployment was 11.7 per cent. We reduced it to 7.3 per cent and it is back up to 10.3 per cent. That is what we must concentrate on very vigorously-
I think my hon. friend would be encouraged by the fact that all of the fundamentals are in place that will inspire job creation, thereby lowering the unemployment rate. Surely, even with this difficulty, the hon. leader of the NDP should be ready to stand up and acknowledge this. When the rest of the world is saying that Canada is number one, why does the leader of the NDP not take some pleasure in it as well?

Mr. Speaker, I would suggest that the Prime Minister start listening to Canadians. Certainly the Prime Minister will have to admit that out of the G-7 countries, Canada has the highest unemployment and that is a tragedy for Canada and for Canadians.
The Prime Minister has made it clear that he has no intention of changing the economic direction of this government. I say to the Prime Minister then that the country will ask for that direction change. He should call an election and let the people of Canada make their comment on this government's economic policies.

I come back to my earlier point. In the last week the IMF and the United Nations said that Canada was the best place in the world in which to live and my hon. friend cannot find any sunshine in that news.

How does the minister justify the fact that some of these contracts were made without any public tendering process when, first of all, that is contrary to Treasury Board guidelines, and second, is contrary to the professed statement of his colleague, the Minister of Supply and Services, a week ago who bragged about his success in creating a procurement system that was more visibly open and fair to all potential suppliers. How does the minister answer that?

He has announced base closings in Toronto, Moncton, and elsewhere and the construction of new bases, contrary to the recommendations of his department and before a report of the special committee he established to recommend a fair and impartial process for base realignment.
How can the minister proceed on base rationalization contrary to the recommendations of his department and in the absence of any recommendations whatsoever from his own advisory group on defence infrastructure?

have a supplementary question, Mr. Speaker.

On the question of sales of products that are being made in prisons, we have checked very carefully with the Chinese. We have been told that none of the products they have sold to us are made in prisons and we are monitoring that question very, very closely.

Will the government assure us that it will not put any taxpayers' dollars or loan guarantees into the development of the Three Gorges dam project?

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
The Prime Minister campaigned in Hamilton during the last federal election saying his trade policies, his tax policies, his dollar policies were going to lead to good times for Hamilton. Last week, Dofasco announced that it was closing the doors on the first foundry which started that operation 70 years ago.
Why is the Prime Minister letting Hamiltonians down? What can he say now to 1,200 people in my riding who were last week declared redundant, largely as a result of the policies of his government?

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I guess the hon. member might understand that Canadian industry is going through a restructuring and modernization process.
April 27, 1992

The hon. member said herself that the plant was some 70 years old, I believe. Plants do run out of steam and must be reorganized. They must be remodelled and must be re-energized. That is going on not only in this country. It is going on around the world right now.

Mr. Speaker, the only thing that is running out of steam is this government.

My hon. friend quite properly points to the difficult situation that we face in areas across the country-Hamilton is one-in regard to the steel industry where there has been a loss of jobs because of a rationalization process that has been ongoing for some considerable period of years.
Competitiveness, because of new plants in Brazil, because of new plants coming in Korea and in Taiwan, is causing-
We are more competitive than they are.

In point of fact, their market share internationally has grown very considerably in the steel business where ours has dropped.

That would indicate to international consumers that we are perhaps not as competitive as we once were. The fact of the matter is that with the low interest rates which are at the lowest in some 19 years, with the low inflation rates which are the lowest of the G-7 countries and with an infusion of new investment capital, we should be able to make improvements in some important areas, including Hamilton.
I look forward to working with my hon. friend, the member for Hamilton, to make things better for the people of that area.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister who has spoken forcefully of his commitment to human rights internationally. Canadians learned last week of a massive RCMP witch-hunt in the late 1950s and 1960s targeting gay men in the federal Public Service, a witch-hunt which was directed by the cabinet character deviate committee and led to hundreds of people losing their jobs and thousands of files being opened.
Will the Prime Minister now agree to order an independent public inquiry into these shameful practices which in at least one instance that I know of led to a suicide? Will he tell this House when his government will finally act on its promise to amend the Canadian Human Rights Act to ensure that this will never ever happen in Canada again?

Mr. Speaker, along with my hon. friend and others I read the report of this that took place some 25 or 30 years ago. The passage of time, based on what I have seen, certainly does not make it any less odious. This would appear to be one of the great outrages and violations of fundamental human liberty that one would have seen for an extended period of time.
I do not know much beyond what I have read because of the manner in which documents are kept, but I have instructed the Clerk of the Privy Council to bring forward for consideration ways that we might examine this more carefully because on its face it would appear to be a fundamental violation of the rights of Canadians and,- if it is as it has been reported, a most regrettable incident.

April 27, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, I appreciate the Prime Minister's undertaking to look into how a full public inquiry into this matter can in fact take place. However, I want to ask the Prime Minister a supplementary question, not with respect to the history of 25 years ago but today.
Will the Prime Minister finally ensure that the Canadian Human Rights Act is amended to prohibit discrimination based on sexual orientation, to ensure that the Canadian Armed Forces ends its witch-hunts which take place today in Canada, and to ensure that never again will this kind of outrage be perpetrated on any Canadian and that Canadians will be judged on their merit, not on their sexual orientation?

Mr. Speaker, I have to point out to my hon. friend that I did not undertake to look into a full public inquiry, but I commend him on his fast action in regard to that. I undertook to consult with the secretary of the cabinet and to examine how this matter could most appropriately be handled.

The Minister of Justice and others are examining these matters very carefully to see what we can do to advance the cause of the elimination of discrimination in Canada.

The percentage of immature fish had been 40 per cent of the
catches, for not using the appropriate netting, which means the

speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the problem has never been that I need any further proof of what is happening in connection with overfishing beyond the 200-mile limit.

subtopic: ALLOTTED DAY, S. O. 81-REQUEST FOR GENERAL ELECTION
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the motion which has been placed before us today by the opposition House leader calls for an immediate federal general election. I believe he feels that he and his colleagues perceive such an action to be the best way to serve their interests disguised in the venue as the best way, as he says, of serving the interests of Canada.
In some respects I am tempted to agree with him because an election would force the opposition to face the realities which are confronting Canada today and to truly focus on the best interests of Canadians. Rather, however, I believe this motion really focuses on their own perception of their own best interests, prompted solely by polls which give them delusions of grandeur. This motion is really not motivated by the best interests of Canadian citizens at all.
It is interesting to see how the political fish rise to the bait, blind to their real responsibilities by the flash of perceived opportunity and perhaps triggered also by just a little touch of fear.
Imagine the hint of butterflies in their bellies when they realize that their own poll standings have peaked and the government ratings, as low as they have been, have actually commenced to turn? What noble purposes are inspired when we hear the opposition say to themselves: "We had better act now, the news is starting to get good and the government is starting to come on strong".
In the perceived best interests to themselves, and really with no regard to the interests of Canadians at all, the opposition would like to have a federal election before the sands of time run out on them for the third consecutive time.
As I say, I can almost agree with my hon. friend from Cape Breton that a general election should soon be called, except that it would not be in the best interests of Canadians at all, not just yet. A better time will come for the only real poll that counts and it will come after this government has fulfilled its responsibilities in the fashion for which we were elected only three and a half years ago.
But first we must finish our task of serving Canadians and then, in due course, a federal general election will follow. When it comes, there will be a finished and lasting foundation of real service on which to launch it. There will be a clear and compelling vision of the future and the promised potential of that future with which to lead it.
So please mark those words carefully. When that election comes it will not be one designed to serve political purposes for political parties, as this frivolous motion does; rather, it will be one designed solely to serve the people of Canada and to help lead them to their potential. I use the word frivolous advisedly because even the members who advanced this motion know full well that Canada is currently coping with critical concerns that an election would not cure, at least not right now.
What they also know and what Canadian citizens are slowly but surely coming to realize is that this government is addressing those concerns in comprehensive and constructive ways, and cures for them are coming closer
April 27, 1992

and closer. In fact, the consensus is getting stronger and the news is getting better almost every day.
Let me give you some examples. First, we all know that the entire world is struggling through a deep recession. Here in Canada the effects are very distressing on many people. We certainly have a lot of progress yet to make in turning our economy around and helping Canadians get back to work.
Yet, as difficult as our share of this recession may be, we are establishing strong footings for our recovery with actions such as an inflation rate currently under 2 per cent and interest rates which have dropped by almost half in little more than a year. And no less an authority than the International Monetary Fund has predicted that Canada will lead the G-7 countries in the path upward out of this recession, predicting solid beginnings of growth in the last half of 1992 and strong economic performance in 1993.
Second, about the good news, it has become common knowledge that over the decades of Liberal government Canada's productivity and our industrial competitive position eroded dramatically by world standards. It seems that the entire Canadian workplace became caught up in the easy life of higher spending and lower performance which characterized the 1970s and the early 1980s.
With the introduction of the free trade agreement in 1989, Canadian businesses were offered the prospect of the largest single market in the world in which to sell their goods. They were also compelled to face the reality of world competition where productivity really counts.
Naturally, we experienced some difficult adjustment problems and the transition to free trade has not been easy. But the direction has been the right one.
It must indeed be gratifying to all Canadians, and indeed worrisome to the opposition, to read business reports last week that indicate Canadian manufacturing is soundly re-developing its competitive edge and our industries are on the mend. This is another strong signal that the right policy actions are producing successful and extremely important results.
Third and best of all, it is little wonder that the opposition members are in a state of panic for a federal election when they see the handwriting on the wall. It says that despite the recession, despite our economic
Supply
difficulties, despite our constitutional dilemma, despite the criticism that has been heaped upon the government, despite the sense of malaise that seems to have gripped our entire country and to which the members opposite have contributed in this debate thus far today, despite it all, the United Nations has just declared that Canada is the best place in the world in which to live.
What a powerful and momentous testimonial that surely is. Yet I am sure that it really does not surprise most Canadians, for many of us know just how fortunate we are to call this country our own.
Just stop to think of it. While the United Nations has not said that Canada is perfect by any means, it has said that we are favoured with the highest quality of life of any nation. Surely there is a message in that for all of us. Surely that means that we should turn our faces into the winds of the world. Surely we should stand a little taller and walk a little quicker and talk a little stronger. Surely it is time that we Canadians from all walks of life come to our senses and commence to concentrate on our profound potential and not on our few passing failures, on our strengths and not on our weaknesses, on our assets and not on our liabilities, on our hopes and dreams and not on lost opportunities.
I think this motion really is an insult to Canadians because it attempts to wrap up all of our problems and all of our potential into a veil of partisan politics. It endeavours to trivialize the struggle we are going through to build our nation by reducing that mission to an opportunistic election call. It demonstrates the apathy, the irony and indeed the hypocrisy of the opposition members in their bewildered and exhausted and frustrated view of our nation as nothing more than a prospective instrument for their own gratification.
Canadians know that it is not quite time yet for an election. They also know that there are real issues to be more fully resolved before we go to the polls. Canadians also know what the United Nations is telling us about our country, that it is almost too good to be true, that it is a model for economic prosperity even in these worst of times, that it is an example of social justice to be the envy of the world, and that it is a nation where entrepreneurial spirit is moved to flourish, that we are a people who give priority to environmental stability and cultural integrity, that we are virtually the promised land for the coming century.

April 27, 1992
Supply
This motion before us today does little more than attempt to add to the spirit of negativism in Canada with its ill-concealed hand-wringing of distress and discouragement. Do you think that Canadians will really believe that an immediate general election will cure our economic problems or will bring resolution to our constitutional deliberations, or will advance the initiatives of the green plan for environmental renewal, or will advance the development of our diversified cultural identity? No. They will see this motion for what it is, a weak and dispirited response by the opposition to all of the great issues of the day for Canada, a statement of ineptitude to effectively deal with those great challenges except by the desolate call of the empty politician with nothing left to offer except "let's call an election and hope for the best".
It is time to stop that negative talk in Canada. We have too much going for us in our future and it is time to move on with vigour and momentum, with confidence and courage. It is time to stop beefing about everything that is wrong with our country. It is time to start bragging about the much larger abundance of what is right with it.
To state it plainly, and hopefully not at the risk of using unparliamentary language, for every Canadian in every corner of this country and for every politician of every party, it is time to change our attitudes. Particularly to those on the opposite benches I would say this: Truly it is time to stop bitching about Canada and time to start boasting about it. The future is ours. Let us seize it.
The enviable position which Canada is developing among the nations of the world is not happening by accident. It is the result of the Canadian population and its government committing to some fundamental principles. They have been instrumental in guiding us to make difficult decisions which have pointed us in sound directions.
First of all, Canadians generally and this government in particular have been willing to face the stark realities of excess and inefficiency from previous administrations and to demonstrate the will to cope with the need for change.
We have accepted the responsibility to find new solutions and we have introduced difficult and sometimes daring measures to create and accomplish them.
The first principle has been to accept our responsibilities and not to hide or run from them, as calling a premature election would be the opposition's way of doing this.
The second principle has been to recognize the lasting truth about democracy. The government must always be of the people, by the people and for the people. The ultimate creation of progress in any society is through the combined efforts of its citizens. To a greater degree than ever before in our history Canada has been governed in close consultation and in continuing communication with its population. That second principle displays the knowledge by this government that it is the role of government to serve the people of Canada and to serve them consistently and well until our mandate to do so has been fulfilled; not as this opposition would have us do, merely to seek re-election when the time is perceived to be right for the opposition.
The third principle, which the previous Liberal government ignored for more than a decade and a half, is that a strong economic foundation is fundamental to the total well-being of any nation. Without economic health and prosperity that will eventually touch the lives of all Canadians it would be impossible to deliver lasting social justice.
Unless our country's economic house is in order we would never be able to sustain its social furnishings. Thus, this government has committed itself to a plan of economic initiatives that is already producing effective results and providing a strong basis of confidence to carry us into the next century. As the opposition well knows, those economic signals will become even stronger as the next federal election draws ever nearer.
The fourth principle is the most important one of all-the determination to keep Canada whole. It is to realize the total power and potential of this country is greater than merely the sum of its parts. It is to ensure our rich diversity is nurtured and maintained. It is to reaffirm that Canadians always come together as one proud and unified country. That principle has been challenged and tested in recent years almost to the
April 27, 1992

breaking point, and yet the bonds of unity still hold. New evidence is emerging every day that lasting Canadian unity will prevail.
In the months ahead we shall see confirmation of those commitments for the constitutional integrity of our country and this government will ensure the constructive conclusion of that process. It is hard to imagine how even the opposition would dare to dally with election talk until Canada's constitutional resolutions are in place.
Those are some of the principles and there are some more by which this government and the people of Canada have conducted their public affairs on behalf of this nation over recent years. It is worth reflecting upon some of the policies, programs and actions which have been taken to fulfil those purposes as contained within those principles.
The programs and the priorities of this government were signalled in the throne speech of 1989 when five specific directions were identified: financial stability, economic growth, environmental integrity, a caring and compassionate society, and the lasting unity of the nation. Those commitments have continued to move steadily forward, all part of a deliberate plan to fulfil the goals and aspirations of Canadians. We still have a long way to go but truly we can take heart and encouragement from the recognition that even in these early stages that plan for the coming century is succeeding.
In terms of public financial stability the government has acted decisively to control its own expenditures and costs. Major long-term moves for economic growth have been made. The free trade agreement has opened the largest market in the world to Canadian entrepreneurs.
Equally in a world context, the environmental imperative cannot be ignored. This government continues to act aggressively and invest wisely to implement the principles of sustainable development. Nothing more dramatically illustrates Canada's environmental commitment than our Green Plan, the first major initiative of this nature by any nation. It is a comprehensive spectrum of projects, programs and measures being systematically introduced and carried out over a six-year period at a total cost of $3 billion. There are many more initiatives of that nature to contemplate.
Supply
As a caring and compassionate society, Canada has been demonstrated to have few peers. Our social safety net is one of the best in the world and our unemployment insurance program and our medicare system are the envy of even our largest neighbours.
Finally, and more fundamentally challenging and compelling than any other current issue before us, we must preserve and sanctify the political and spiritual unity of our country. No government in Canada's history has ever committed itself so strongly and so completely to that task.
I know I am running out of time and I would like to say that, truly, these final constitutional measures or movements which our country is experiencing at the same time must be the most meaningful developments in the mandate of this government. As significant as all of the other principles and policies and initiatives may be, they pale by comparison to the great challenge of preserving Canada as a strong and unified nation. Frankly our promise and potential for the future hinge on keeping Canada whole.
That remains the primary purpose we must pursue and it is one that we must simply bring to resolution in fulfilment of our responsibilities and our mandate.
That is the goal that I remain confident we will soon achieve and it is in that fashion that we can absolutely best serve Canadians in this and future generations.
On the occasion of the 125th anniversary of Confederation, the reality of one Canada must continue to be a compelling commitment and our proud legacy to the next 125 years of Canadian history yet to come.
Then and only then, with the constitutional resolution firmly in place before us and with the consensus for Canadian unity clearly established beneath us, the prospect of a federal general election will undoubtedly be addressed by the sole leader who can make that decision. When that time comes I predict that the official opposition will not be nearly so anxious for it as it so hungrily appears to be today.

That, in the opinion of this House, the interests of Canadians would
be best served by an immediate federal general election.

Supply
In my province of Prince Edward Island, the unemployment rate is 17.1 per cent. Since I was elected to Parliament in 1988, I have never known a time when so many people have talked to me about the employment situation. They are people who are looking for jobs, or if they have a job they are concerned that they may lose it.
I have never had so many young people come into my office looking for employment. It is a tragedy that approximately 400,000 young people are unemployed in this country. As I stated, it is not only young people. People from many age groups are really suffering.
Every weekend when I return to my constituency, I talk to people of all ages who are feeling stressed out with the anguish of not being able to properly provide for their families' needs. They are feeling the stress of trying to make the mortgage payments or the rent payments, the car payments, put food on the table and to clothe their families adequately. The statistics that I referred to really do not show the whole story. They show the unemployment rate, but that does not include an estimated 99,000 jobless Canadians who have given up finding work. Half of that 99,000 are between the ages of 25 and 44 and almost one-third are from Atlantic Canada. Those 99,000 are people who are also looking for hope. They are people who have given up on this government. They have lost faith in this government's ability to do anything about the economy.
Certainly one of the best ways to get these individuals back on their feet is by calling an election and bringing in a new government to deal with these issues from a fresh perspective.
There was a recent Angus Reid-Southam News poll that provided some evidence on the need for an election. This poll indicated that Canadians believed by almost a two to one margin, and that is a large margin, that the Liberals are best equipped to deal with the economy.
I think it is safe to say that if we had an election today, the election of a Liberal government would immediately pay dividends in rekindling consumer confidence and reinstating economic growth in Canada.
It is very interesting to note that the same poll showed almost the identical two to one margin of confidence in
the Liberals' ability to handle the national unity problems.
The Prime Minister has in recent days hinted at the possible need to hold a national referendum. Certainly our party has been advocating that approach for some time, so it is with pleasure that we recognize and we welcome the Prime Minister's comments. Canadians want to have a say in our constitutional future. In fact, a recent Gallop poll indicated that 62 per cent of Canadians favour a national referendum on any reforms that would amend the Constitution. In Atlantic Canada three out of four easterners are in favour of a referendum and only 6 per cent are opposed.
To have a referendum today with the government at 16 per cent in the polls, with the Canadian economy mired in a recession, with the lack of confidence that the public have in this Prime Minister and this government, it would not be easy to ensure that Canadians vote for a renewed Canada rather than against this Prime Minister and government. There is a danger that the public may be inclined to demonstrate their dissatisfaction with the Tory government by voting against the referendum.
The best way for this government to ensure that this does not take place is to call an election. Let the people decide who they want to lead this constitutional battle.
I know that my time is getting short so I simply want to sum up by stating that Canadians are disenchanted. The once buoyant, the always reserved Canadian confidence appears to be diminishing. Many Canadians, as I have stated, have given up on finding a job or they are really worried about the job that they have because they may be laid off.
We need a new government that can rekindle our pride and rebuild our confidence in ourselves. We need a Prime Minister who people do not regard as a source of distrust but as a source of inspiration.
Our countiy is going through some veiy difficult times in our history. We have pulled together through difficult times in the past and I am confident we can do it again.
The problems before us today are very great indeed and the efforts and participation of all Canadians will be needed. It is essential that the leadership of our countiy have the respect, the support and the ability to motivate Canadians. The present government does not have that respect and support.

Therefore, in the interests of our economic potential, national unity and our future as a nation, we call upon this Prime Minister today to do what is best for our country.
